Jim Jordan (R-OH) is Interviewed about the RNC, Postmaster Testimony and Big Tech; Nikki Haley is Interviewed about the RNC, Democrats and Socialism, and Biden's Foreign Policy; The GOP Is Promising Four More Years Of An American First Agenda; Markets Are On The Rise Once Again; Marco Making Landfall But The Real Threat Is Coming From Tropical Storm Laura; There's A Fight To Save New York City After Many Claim The Big Apple Is Dead.2020-08-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:10ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTDominick Tavella, Sean O'Hara, Sarah Frey, Jim Jordan, Nikki HaleyNEWSFinancial082502cb.231Rep. Jim Jordan (R-OH) is Interviewed about the RNC, Postmaster Testimony and Big Tech; Nikki Haley is Interviewed about the RNC, Democrats and Socialism, and Biden's Foreign Policy; The GOP Is Promising Four More Years Of An American First Agenda; Markets Are On The Rise Once Again; Marco Making Landfall But The Real Threat Is Coming From Tropical Storm Laura; There's A Fight To Save New York City After Many Claim The Big Apple Is Dead.Maria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Matt Schlapp, Phil Flynn, Jon Hilsenrath, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back, good Tuesday morning everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I am Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, August 25.

Your top stories right now, 7:00 am on the East coast.

RNC night one in the books. The GOP promising four more years of an American first agenda.

I'll be speaking with Ohio Congressman Jim Jordan along with former Ambassador to the U.N. Nikki Haley this hour after both last -- spoke last night in highlighted speeches. Plus, New York Congresswoman Elise Stefanik is here, she will be speaking tomorrow night, we'll get a preview.

Markets on the rise once again this morning after another historic day, driven by positive trade talks between the United States and China.

The Dow Industrials this morning up almost 200 points. You've got a gain of two/thirds of 1 percent, the Nasdaq up 19 and the S&P Futures up 14.75. The Nasdaq hitting -- and the S&P 500 hitting all time highs yesterday.

Take a look and the markets were higher across the board with the Dow Industrials up 378 at 4:00 o'clock on Wall Street. The Nasdaq was up 67 and the S&P up 34.

Investigating the origins of the Russia Probe, Senator Lindsey Graham telling me that the FBI showed a, quote, double standard in stopping a FISA warrant against the Clinton Campaign.

Former Foreign Policy Advisor to Donald Trump Carter Page is here once again to talk about that.

Plus Jim Comey's claim that he is not a target in the John Durham criminal probe.

Chaos in Wisconsin for a second night in a row. Rioters setting fires and smashing windows, calling for justice days after a black man is shot by police.

Marco making landfall, but the real threat coming from Tropical Storm Laura. It is expected to become a major hurricane. We will follow all of that for you.

Saving America's farmers, the industry still suffering even with strong crops. What is needed to grow business today?

And the fight to save New York City, at least one critic says the Big Apple is dead. One famous funny man comes to the city's defense.

"Mornings with Maria" is live right now.

European markets this morning are higher, take a look at the indexes there, with the FTSE 100 up 11.5, the CAC 40 is up 42 and the DAX Index is up 104.

In Asia overnight more of a mixed story, Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin speaking by phone with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He to discuss the phase one China deal. All the major induces, as you can see, were fractioning (ph) moving, although the KOSPI in Korea was up one and two-thirds percent.

During the conversation all morning this morning Dagen McDowell, Jon Hilsenrath and Matt Schlapp. It is great to have everybody this morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS HOST: Great to see you.

MATT SCHLAPP, FOX NEWS POLITICAL CONTRIBUTOR: Hey Maria.

BARTIROMO: And the top stories that we are watching this morning, some of the biggest names in the Republican Party making the case for President Trump last night, as the pro-America candidate on night one of the RNC.

Many of the opening speeches took place at the Andrew Melon Auditorium in Washington, D.C., unlike the DNC that was mostly virtual.

The GOP formally renominating President Trump and Vice President Pence with an in-person roll call in Charlotte, North Carolina, allowing six delegates from each state.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(SHOUTING)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart. You're incredible warriors, you have incredible strength. We have to win, this is the most important election in the history of our country. Our country is counting on it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: President Trump will officially accept the nomination on Thursday. Tonight's theme, Land of Opportunity, with First Lady Melania Trump, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Eric and Tiffany Trump set to speak at tonight's event.

Picking up strength meanwhile, Tropical Storm Laura is on track to become a major hurricane within the next 48 hours. The system churning toward Texas and Louisiana now. Laura being blamed for at least nine deaths in the Caribbean.

Meanwhile, Marco has been downgraded to a tropical depression, the storm making landfall near the mouth of the Mississippi River yesterday. Marco could still bring heavy rain to parts of the Gulf Coast.

And the forecast is improving for firefighters in California this morning, hoping to get an upper hand the fast-moving wildfires burning across the state. More than 14,000 fire crews are battling three massive fires started by lightning in the San Francisco Bay area. The fire scorching more than 1.2 million acres, destroying more than 1,200 homes and buildings. At least seven people have died.

Unrest in Kenosha meanwhile, hundreds of demonstrators in the Wisconsin city setting buildings and cars on fire overnight.

The city, the latest flashpoint of unrest following the police shooting of Jacob Blake, a black man. According to court records a warrant for his arrest was filed last month for criminal trespass, domestic abuse and third-degree sexual assault. Blake was also arrested in 2018 for driving without a license.

The National Guard has been called in to help with the violence.

A 33-year-old man apparently the world's first person to be reinfected by COVID-19. Researchers say the man living in Hong Kong first tested positive on March 26, with symptoms, then again on August 15, but with no symptoms. He had just traveled to Europe. The discovery raising more questions about how long a person is immune after infection.

Time for the Word on Wall Street. Joining me right now is PRICE Futures Group Senior Market Analyst and Fox Business Contributor Phil Flynn. Labenthal Global Advisors President Dominick Tavella and PacersETF Distributors President Sean O'Hara.

First up, great to see everybody this morning, thank you so much for being here.

PHIL FLYNN, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

DOMINICK TAVELLA, LABENTHAL GLOBAL ADVISORS PRESIDENT: Good morning.

SEAN O'HARA, PACERSETF DISTRIBUTORS PRESIDENT: Good morning Maria.

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about these markets that will now quite. Futures up again. All three major induces with major gains yesterday, adding to it this morning. The Dow jumping above 28,000 for the first time in six months. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq seeing record high closes.

You got a major day yesterday, but the market is up almost 200 points right now, Dominick. To what do you attribute this euphoria and can we expect this market to continue surging?

TAVELLA: Well, I think we're seeing a little bit better breadth than we have in the past, but overall it's still these five stocks that dominate the headlines. And we're getting an awful lot of new investors coming into the market. We see what's going on at Robinhood, the number of new accounts that are open and specifically the kind of stocks that they're buying.

And so when you're thinking about Apple specifically and Tesla, they're really driving the markets, they're really pushing these markets much higher than really they should be. So, I think in the short run we've got to be a little careful here. I think they've gotten way over their skis.

BARTIROMO: So, you want to sell into some rallies then, Dominick?

TAVELLA: We've been trimming back, absolutely. We did our first sale of equities this week, we lowered our equity exposure by 5 percent. I don't want to -- I'm not predicting a major correction here.

I do think though that when you look at that 1 percent of the stocks of the S&P 500 represent 25 percent of the overall weighting and everyday the phone rings, should we being buying Apple now or should we buy it after the split. It's just crazy Maria.

We -- you have to look at where the value of the market is. Look at the mid-cap sector of the S&P 500, still negative about 6 percent of the year and the small-cap sector in the S&P still negative in average of 11 percent for the year. There's value there. It's time to start rotating your portfolio. Sell a little bit of your winners and start accumulating some of the things that have not done as well.

BARTIROMO: All right, next up, the storm threat to the Gulf of Mexico. We are watching these storms today. Oil and gasoline surging to five month highs this week. Around 82 percent of oil production suspended by mid-day yesterday in the Gulf of Mexico.

Tropical Storm Laura expected to strengthen to a major hurricane, so we could have even more impact. Phil, how do you see things in the oil markets given what we're seeing in the weather?

FLYNN: You know, I think this is the most significant challenge we've seen from these storms in many, many years, because it isn't just one, Maria, it's two, right? We -- first we had to shut down production for tropical depression now Marco and now a possible cat-4, which means production in the Gulf is going to be closed down more than in recent memory.

Now, the bigger concern I have right now is for gasoline prices. We have over a million barrels a day of refining capacity shut in because of these storms and the track of the storm is going right over refinery row, so there's a possibility that these refiners could be down for a period of time.

That means higher gasoline prices, and we're already seeing it reflected in the pump already. So, it's amazing how quickly those prices go up when they want to go up when prices start to get tight.

BARTIROMO: And then there's this, the Dow shakeup this morning, the Blue Chip Index swapping out three components, Apple's four for one stock split will reduce the benchmark's exposure to the information technology sector, so they're putting Salesforce, that will replace Exxon Mobile, Amgen will replace Pfizer and Honeywell will replace Raytheon Technologies, that all happens on August 31, Sean.

And we've got these stocks moving up this morning as a result, because we know that when you're in the Dow 30 it allows more -- those money managers that track the Dow 30 will now be buying those stocks in the Dow 30, so it's much more buying power, which is setting the stocks up.

O'HARA: Yes, and so -- you know -- the affect of this kind of a couple of things. Although there's more money that tracks the S&P 500 because it's a little bit broader, but the Apple reducing its exposure because of the split or Dow reducing Apple's exposure because of their stock split will lower the weight.

And so, what we'll likely see is a little bit more of a disconnect between the Dow and the S&P 500, for example, or the Dow and the Nasdaq 100.

It will also probably lower a little bit the overall P.E. ratio, which I think people are worried about as you take a name like Apple that's trading at almost 40 times earnings and reduce its exposure and when it was a fairly big name is these broad indexes that will have a minor affect of lowering overall P.E.s, which may make people a little bit more comfortable.

For the markets to keep going forward from here, really we need two things to happen. We need to have the continued improvement and the pace of opening up the economy, and then the second thing we need is the other 495 stocks in the S&P 500 and the other 95 stocks in the, say, Nasdaq 100 to start picking up.

You know, I was talking to a colleague yesterday and said would you rather buy Apple or American Airlines here? I own Apple personally, and I'm thinking maybe I might actually put a little American Airlines in my portfolio because if you think about American Airlines and you think let's say a two-year time horizon there's probably more upside in a name like American Airlines than there is in Apple if we are able to open up the economy and if air travelers feel more comfortable about getting on the place, so it's a really interesting time. So thanks - I mean, so I'm being told to wrap, so I'm sorry.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Phil Flynn, Dominick Tavella, Sean O'Hara, it's great to have you this morning. Thank you so much, gentlemen. Quick break, and then coming up Ohio Congressman, House Judiciary Committee Member, Jim Jordan, on the first night of the Republican National Convention. Former U.S. Ambassador to the U.N., Nikki Haley, is here speaking at the RNC last night talking about the Trump foreign policy agenda. In the 8 a.m. hour this morning, former Foreign Policy Advisor to Donald Trump, Carter Page, is here on the latest fallout from the Russia investigation along with former Deputy Chief of Staff to President Obama, Jim Messina, joining us with his take on the first night of the RNC. Plus Jerry Seinfeld hitting back, the comedian defending New York City. You are watching Mornings with Maria live on Fox Business. Stay with us.

Welcome back. Not until 2021, that is when New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio predicts indoor dining will return to the Big Apple. It is a critical time for New York restaurants as the warm days are numbered for outdoor dining. A recent Wall Street Journal article highlighting new thinking that COVID lockdowns were overly blunt and costly. This is important, Dagen, because you are talking about industries that will not come back. I spoke to a restaurant guy just yesterday, and he said, Maria, so many restaurants have closed down. They can't make it. They're not going to make it unless indoor dining comes back. Your take?

MCDOWELL: These are - so we know that Bill de Blasio hates the rich and the - he just acts like rich people don't pay taxes and don't basically support New York City. OK, we got that. I do also think he hates everybody because when you talk about restaurants and keeping restaurants closed for this long, you're talking about destroying the livelihoods of families. You're talking about destroying jobs permanently for people who work in the front of the house, waiters, waitresses, and people who work in kitchens across this city. It will be - if we keep these restaurants closed - and by the way I want to point out Cheryl Casone reported this on the news channel earlier, the infection rate, you know, the number of positive tests coming back in New York state has been below 1 percent for 17 days in a row. There is no reason that these restaurants can't open in a safe way to ensure that they are around for months if not years to come.

BARTIROMO: This is a serious thing. They are not going to come back in some capacity. Jon Hilsenrath, how do you see it?

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Well I mean, New York has an especially big problem when it comes to restaurants because rents are so high and taxes are so high. You have to pack people very closely together in New York, restaurants to cover all your costs, and that becomes a health hazard in a coronavirus era, so it's a big problem. You know, I think that we've learned as a country that we need to find some alternative to the very tight grip shutdowns that we did back in March and April. You know, one of the obvious alternatives that seems to work is wearing masks, you know, and I think that's the kind of compromise that the whole country has to be making right now especially in cities to try to get business back to - going again without suffering the consequences of such big shutdowns.

BARTIROMO: Yes, for sure. Well, we'll see how this plays out. We will take a break. Yes, go ahead, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: New COVID cases in the U.S. fall to lowest level in more than two months, and I would credit mask wearing. I was down in Virginia, rural Virginia. They hand out masks at the grocery store now, and I actually yelled at somebody who refused to put a mask on. I yelled him out in the parking - yelled him out of the store into the parking lot I was so angry. I was like don't come in here and make people sick if you're not going to wear a mask, so there's that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well no, it's true. I mean, it makes people feel better, and Matt Schlapp, really what we need is confidence. People need confidence to go back to restaurants. If it's masks, it's masks. If it's, you know, social distancing, that's what it is. You need confidence.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: We will take - Matt, you didn't hear my I guess. Matt Schlapp -

(CROSSTALK)

SCHLAPP: Oh, no -

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- we want to get back to you in a minute.

SCHLAPP: -- OK, sounds good. I have a lot of opinions to share Dagen (ph).

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: You're staring there blank face at me. I'm like what? Hello? Matt?

(LAUGHTER)

SCHLAPP: Hello? Again, I have to - what's going on here?

BARTIROMO: All right. Yes, yes. We're going to take a break and then we're going to come back to you. Fresh greens are making a comeback. We are speaking with one farmer about the positive growth. She turned her life and her family's life around in America's heartland. Wait till you see her story. Then the power of The Office. A heartfelt reaction from one star after wrapping up the TV favorite. You're watching Mornings with Maria live on Fox Business.

Welcome back. Going green. Fresh produce making a big comeback packing grocery store shelves. It is a huge rebound for farmers recently destroying their harvest because of COVID-19 supply chain delays. The uptick is positive, but it's unclear if American farmers are out of the woods just yet. My next guest owns farmland across seven states and is one of the country's largest fresh produce growers. She is the author of the new book "The Growing Season". Sarah Frey is with us now. Sarah, it is great to have you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

SARAH FREY, "THE GROWING SEASON" AUTHOR: Good morning, Maria. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: You have such a great story in terms of building your business. I want to get to that, but first tell me how things are going in terms of farming. How is business? The fresh vegetable and fruit juice market could be really more than an $8 billion business in the U.S. over the next few years. Is that right?

FREY: It is. It is. You know, the restaurant industry as you know has taken quite a hit, and in the fresh produce industry we're losing about a billion dollars every single week in our industry. There are about 250,000 fresh produce farms across the country, and those farms are really struggling right now. We need to get things, you know, back open.

BARTIROMO: What do farmers need right now, Sarah?

FREY: You know, farmers really - you know, they need their markets to open back up. They need that restaurant business to come back. I know from our own personal experience we farm fresh fruits and vegetables in seven different states. Fortunately for Frey Farms most of our business was heavily weighted grocery retail, so companies like Walmart, Kroger, Publics, those stores and those retailers are doing fantastic, but on the beverage side of our business, you know, we do business with great American companies like Subway that provide fresh, very affordable food. And so, we've seen our beverage sales really decline, you know, since March. And they're starting to come back, and we're really rooting for the franchisees at those stores to, you know, get back up and running, but we just need things to open back up.

BARTIROMO: And you juice sometimes the imperfect fruit that would otherwise be wasted, right? Tell me about your beverage business.

FREY: We do. We do. So Frey Farms is best known as the nation's largest pumpkin farm, but we actually sell more watermelons than we do pumpkins, although it's kind of a pumpkiny time of the year right now. And we make watermelon juice.

We start out by making watermelon juice on the farm. So, we would take the imperfect melons and we would juice them on the farm, bottle that juice, and it's -- it's sold under the brand Tsamma, T-S-A-M-M-A.

And it -- why the funky name? It's -- Tsamma is the mother of all watermelons and since we're farmer geeks that's why we -- that's why we named our juice Tsamma.

BARTIROMO: I love it. So Sarah, you sell more pumpkins than any other producer in the country right now. Do you expect any change in demand this year? And what about the government's aid, was that -- was that a big game changer for the farmers?

FREY: It wasn't necessarily helpful to us in our business, although some of the commodities that we grow are going to get a little bit of help here. I think watermelons just made the list.

But, we shipped thousands of loads of fresh fruits and vegetables. Beginning in March I think we shipped -- like in Q2 we shipped nearly 2,000 semi loads of fresh watermelons off our farm in Florida and we kept going through COVID.

You know, obviously with worker safety being -- you know -- front of center and one of -- you know -- obviously the most important thing in our -- in our business and being able to continue, and we had to make a decision very early on when we were deciding how many acres of pumpkins to plant her in the Midwest.

And one of the -- one of the things that we -- you know -- had to take into consideration was are people still going to want to -- want to buy a pumpkin this year? Should we plant as many?

But, we leaned in and we actually planted more pumpkins than -- than we ever have in the past, because I think -- I think pumpkins are a low ticket item that bring joy and happiness into people's homes. And, you know, pumpkins make people happy, so I think -- I think we could all use a little bit more of that now.

BARTIROMO: You're right. You wrote a great memoir, "The Growing Season: How I Built a New Life and Saved an American Farm." Real quick, on building a new life, Sarah, how'd you do that?

FREY: You know, Maria, if you've had an opportunity to read the book, it's -- it's really, in my life, I have the -- you know -- the same philosophy that I have in business and that's how do you -- how do you look through life's imperfections and how do you -- how do you look at challenges and overcome those challenges. How do you look for the good and find the greater purpose.

It's no different than what we do with the ugly fruit in the fresh produce industry when -- when we take that fruit that might be visually imperfect and we turn it into delicious beverages or healthy ingredients, we find that fruit's greater purpose.

And in the book "The Growing Season" that -- you know -- it's a memoir, so it's some very personal stories in -- in the book about my life. But, the overall essence of the book is looking through the imperfections to find the good.

BARTIROMO: Love it. Sarah, it's great to have you this morning. Congrats to you. We'll see you soon. Thank you so much.

Sarah Frey, check out the book, "The Growing Season."

FREY: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Tuesday, August 25th. A look at markets right here at 7:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Futures on the rise this morning once again after another historic day driven by positive trade talks between the U.S. and China. The Dow futures are up 180 points. That's two-thirds of 1 percent. The Nasdaq has turned negative. The Nasdaq has been the leading group in this market. It is now lower by 12.5. The S&P 500 up 12.75. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin speaking by phone with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 hitting all-time highs yesterday.

European markets in the green this morning. Take a look. The -- yesterday the market was up strongly with the Dow up 378 points and the momentum continues in Europe. The FT 100's up 10, the CAC quarante is up 41, and the DAX index up 92.

In Asia overnight a mixed story. Take a look. Best performer was Korea. The Kospi index up one and two-thirds percent.

Meanwhile this, the California Supreme Court overturning the death sentence of Scott Peterson.

Cheryl Casone with the details on that now.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: That's right, Maria.

California's high court ruled that significant errors were made in jury selection but they did uphold his murder conviction. Prosecutors have the option of seeking the death penalty again. Peterson was found guilty in 2004 of killing his pregnant wife, Lacey. His lawyer says that he hasn't told Peterson about the ruling because of a Covid-19 outbreak at that prison where he currently is residing.

Top trade negotiators for the U.S. and China say they are committed to the phase one trade deal signed in January. U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He discussed the agreement in a video conference late yesterday. Not a lot of details of the call were released, but Lighthizer's office said topics included significant increases in purchases of U.S. products by China. Tensions between the U.S. and China intensifying recently with the president threatening to ban Chinese apps TikTok and WeChat here in this country.

And, finally this, hitting a record high. Apple shares closing at more than $500 each yesterday. Investors are racing to beat that eligibility deadline for the company's upcoming stock split.

Want to take a look at Apple in the pre-market right now. It's actually just a little bit lower by half a percent, but that four for one stock split is going to take place next Monday.

Meantime, a new report is swirling about the new iPhone. Apple leaked a September 10th event date on YouTube. The new device reportedly, Maria, going to be the first Apple with 5G. The first Apple phone with 5G. We're ready.

Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, thank you so much, Cheryl.

The first night of the 2020 Republican National Convention now in the books. High profile names in the Republican Party making the case for President Trump as the pro-America candidate.

Ohio Congressman Jim Jordan spoke last night, recounting an emotional time when President Trump comforted his family after his nephew's death. Jordan also slammed Democrats, arguing that they support violent protesters.

Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Look at what's happening in American cities. Cities all run by Democrats. Crime, violence, and mob rule.

Democrats won't let you go to work, but they'll let you riot. And Democrats won't let you go to school, but they'll let you go loot.

President Trump has fought against each of their crazy ideas.

They tried the Russia hoax, the Mueller investigation and the fake impeachment. But in spite of this unbelievable opposition, this president has done what he said he would of do, taxes cut, regulations reduced, economy growing, lowest unemployment in 50 years, out of the Iran deal, embassy in Jerusalem, hostages home from North Korea, a new USMCA agreement and, of course, he's building the wall and rebuilding our economy as we speak.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Ohio Congressman, House Judiciary Committee and House Oversight and Reform Committee member, Jim Jordan.

And, Congressman, it's always a pleasure to see you. Congratulations on the speech last night.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Thank you, Maria. Good to be with you this morning.

BARTIROMO: So tell me what you think is resonating most or what did resonate. You made a -- you made a good point, justification of basically showing what the Republicans are doing in terms of law and order, in terms of insuring that the economy comes back, versus what you're seeing on the other side.

JORDAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Is that what you're goal was?

JORDAN: Well, I think that was part of it. I think really what came through last night, the president said this Sunday night on your network, he talked about the amazing potential of the American people. And I think that was the theme last night.

I mean you think about Nikki Haley's story. You think about Senator Scott's story, his humble beginnings, now a United States senator. You think about Herschel Walker's life. You think about those frontline healthcare workers, frontline first responders that the president talked to there at the White House, the hostages he met with, the amazing potential of the American people and just the positive feel we got last night.

And I meant what I said in my -- in my -- in my speech that the Republican Party is the pro-America party, the institutions, the values, the principles that make our country great. That's what we need to defend. This president is doing that. That's why I think he's going to get reelected.

BARTIROMO: At the same time, the speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi, called the president, as well as the Republicans in Congress, yesterday, domestic enemies, enemies of the state.

Did you see that?

JORDAN: Yes, that -- I mean she has -- she has said a number of things that just make no sense, that are just flat-out wrong. This president is -- I think he's that rare individual who comes to this town and actually does what he told the American people he was going to do. That's what the American people so appreciate about him. And I had that list of things we talked about.

But you think about this -- just take one example. Take putting the embassy in Jerusalem. The -- for -- for as long as I can remember, every single presidential candidate in either party, in both parties, said, if you elect me, I will put the embassy in Jerusalem. Then they get elected and they come up with a million reasons, the swamp gives them tons of reasons why they can't do it. This president did it. And the response you -- and it worked out fine. But -- but the speaker of the House criticizes the president for doing what he told the American people -- that that's how frustrated, that's how -- that's how, you know, the -- the Democrats have been out to get this president, as you know, Maria, since before he was even elected with the whole Trump/Russia investigation.

So it doesn't -- that's nothing new from her. It is so wrong. And I think the American people see through it. And like I said, I think they're going to elect President Trump as the next president.

BARTIROMO: Yes, no, you went through it, first the -- the Russia collusion hoax and then, you know, the Mueller investigation, the impeachment, you called it the fake impeachment. You're right, they have been out to get him and take him down from day one.

Now there's a Postal Service controversy, Congressman. Walk us through this. Postmaster General Louis DeJoy defending his management of the U.S. Postal Service to the House yesterday amid these concerns that his cost- cutting measures are jeopardizing the agency's ability to serve Americans going into a presidential election.

What's at stake here?

JORDAN: Well, what the Democrats are really trying to do, and this is not me saying this, this is "The Wall Street Journal." This is the latest conspiracy theory from the Democrats. But there's $14 billion cash on hand. They've got a $10 billion line of credit. What he's doing on collection boxes and sorting machines is nothing new. In fact, the Obama/Biden administration, between 2011 and 2016 removed 12,000 collection boxes around the country. So he's doing nothing new.

But the Democrats want to create chaos and confusion because they want to count ballots after Election Day. That's what this is about. You saw what happened in New York. One congressional primary, actually the chairwoman of the committee, the sponsor of the Democrats' bill, Caroline Maloney, her election was June 23rd. She wasn't declared the winner until six weeks later.

In the New Jersey primaries, it took four weeks to count the ballots after the primary election date. And, frankly, look -- go back to the Iowa Democrat caucuses. I don't even know -- I don't know if we still know who won -- who won the Democrat caucus for the -- for the presidential race.

So the Democrats want this chaos and confusion because I believe, and I'm convinced, they know President Trump is going to win on Election Day, but they want to keep counting ballots after Election Day.

So that's what this is really about. They want to send out as many live ballots, mail out as many live ballots as they can around this country and then be counting after -- after the election night, after election night's over.

So, that's what this is about. We need to call it for what it is. And -- but they're attacking the post office for the -- for those reasons. And that's what's -- that's what's scary to me. That's why they're getting so fired up.

But in -- again, in spite of all that, the president's going to win. I can just feel -- you can see it in Ohio.

BARTIROMO: But -- but, Congressman --

JORDAN: I mean he won big in Ohio.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JORDAN: And I think it's going to be even bigger this time.

BARTIROMO: So you don't -- you don't buy the polls then because in the polls he's been lagging.

JORDAN: You can feel it in our state. You see the American flags and Trump signs all over the place.

I was in Youngstown, not in our district, but across the state, Youngstown, a huge crowd at the Youngstown Republican -- it used to be you couldn't find Republicans in the Youngstown area.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JORDAN: But 350 people at this Republican event. You feel the energy building. I think last night was a great kickoff in our convention.

I feel that in Ohio. I feel very good about our state. There's other key states where the president -- and the president's out and about.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JORDAN: While Joe Biden won't leave his home, the president was in Wisconsin, Minnesota, North Carolina just in the last few days. So he's out and about talking to the American people that he cares so much about.

BARTIROMO: So what are you going to do? What are you going to -- I mean, look, most people do not want a socialist agenda. Most people do not want to see $4 trillion in tax increases. So you've -- you've got, you know, the right idea in terms of policy. But what are you going to do to stop cheating if there is cheating in terms of mail-in voting? What about big tech? Congressional lawmakers investigating anti-Republican speech, anti- conservative bias at big tech, turning to Amazon as well, Congressman.

So what about the potential for cheating, whether it's big tech or whether it's mail-in voting? What are you going to do?

JORDAN: Well, we just -- well, you draw attention to it. That's all we can do at this point. You draw attention to it. That's what we did yesterday in this hearing on -- on the Postal Service. You draw attention to when every single time big tech is censoring conservatives, every single time you draw attention to it so the American people understand what's going on.

But we also have to look at legislative solutions. Unfortunately, we can't do that with Jerry Nadler running the Judiciary Committee. We need to win back the House in order to actually accomplish some of those things.

But you draw attention to every single time. When they censor the president, but Twitter also -- at the same time Twitter will allow a statement from -- from the -- the leader of Iran where he actually threatens the safety of American citizens, I mean that's how ridiculous it has gotten.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JORDAN: So you call attention to it every single time so the American people understand.

BARTIROMO: All right.

Congressman, we'll be watching, of course. Very important stuff here.

Congressman Jim Jordan, it's great to see you, sir. Thank you.

JORDAN: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Stay right here. We've got former U.S. ambassador to the U.N., Nikki Haley, coming up next. She spoke at the RNC last night, discussing the Trump foreign policy agenda. We'll talk with her coming up.

You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NIKKI HALEY, FORMER U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE U.N.: This president has a record of strength and success. The former vice president has a record of weakness and failure. Joe Biden is good for Iran and ISIS, great for communist China, and he's a godsend to everyone who wants America to apologize, abstain and abandon our values.

Donald Trump takes a different approach. He's tough on China and he took on ISIS and won. And he tells the world what it needs to hear.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: That was former U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley touting the Trump administration's foreign policy record during night one of the Republican National Convention. Haley, one of the several Republican heavy-hitters to take the stage last night after the party officially nominated President Trump for a second term.

Joining me right now is former U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. herself, former South Carolina governor, Nikki Haley.

Governor, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us. Congratulations on your speech.

NIKKI HALEY, FORMER U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE U.N.: Oh, good morning, Maria. It was a great night last night.

BARTIROMO: So tell me about that. I felt that it was real and there was sincerity because you had real people out there talking about the impact that these policies have had on them.

Is this going to be the theme for the rest of the week? Do you feel that it resonated last night?

HALEY: Well, I think that this week is about truth. I think this week is about facts. What we saw last week was the sky is falling, the world is coming to an end. And this week is a reminder of all of the things President Trump has done in the last three and a half, four years and the progress that can be built on that.

I mean you heard from fantastic people, whether it was Andrew Pollak or Tim Scott, whether it was the Cuban dissident, Herschel Walker, I mean all of these people know the president, know what it's like to interact with him but have felt what it means to really watch his policies take effect.

And, you know, the country is continuing to move in a good direction. We've got to continue with President Trump and Vice President Pence to make that keep going.

BARTIROMO: Well, you talked about your parents, you talked about being born from Indian parents. And I thought it was so real and sincere the way you spoke about that. Let me -- let me ask you about your own plans because a lot of people look at you and they say, well, we wanted her to be the vice president candidate. We know that it is Mike Pence. But would you accept a job in an administration if the president does get a second term?

HALEY: Well, that's nothing that I've talked to the president about. Right now we want to see the president and Vice President Pence get over the finish line in November. I think that's what's most important.

But certainly any chance there is to serve our country, I want to do. And, you know, all that nonsense about me and Pence, he's a dear friend. He's done a great job. He's been loyal to the president and the American people should be very proud.

So, no, I think we have to get them over the finish line and whatever those two need from me or from anyone else, we want to continue our country moving in the right direction.

BARTIROMO: You also spoke out about the potential economic ramifications of a Biden presidency.

Let's' take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HALEY: Last time Joe's boss was Obama. This time, it would be Pelosi, Sanders and the squad. Their vision for America is socialism.

Joe Biden and the socialist left would be a disaster for our economy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So -- so, Governor, we know that a lot of the policies that we're hearing out of AOC and Elizabeth Warren are bordering on socialism, you're right. But when Joe Biden speaks, he tries to, you know, tell people that he's a moderate. In fact, the mainstream media is talking about the party as if it's a moderate. Kamala Harris as well.

So tell us why you believe that it is, in fact, a disaster and it is socialism, because that's not what he says when asked the question.

HALEY: Well, first of all, Joe Biden may have been a moderate a few decades ago, but, I mean, you can't go and increase taxes on 82 percent of the Americans when we're coming, you know, out of a Covid situation and say that you're a moderate. You can't go and ask for all of those mandates based on AOC's green new deal and say that you're a moderate. You can't sit there and allow any conversation about socialism ever taking hold in America and claim to be a moderate.

The truth is that Biden is going to be whoever Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren and AOC tell him to be. And we've seen that. We've watch him through the issues, how he's flip-flopping on the issues. But at the end of the day, he's taking a more progressive stance. He's not taking a more moderate stance and our economy can't afford it. Americans can't afford it.

What we need right now is for -- for a situation where President Trump already took us over the finish line, where we had more people working than ever before. Opportunities for African-Americans, for Hispanics, for women. We were breaking records left and right. That's where we need to go back to.

And, you know, President Trump did it once before. We know he can do it again.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HALEY: We've watched Biden for decades. As a South Carolina governor, I can tell you, they worked against us when we were trying to bring jobs. They certainly didn't try and help us.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about foreign policy. We talked a lot about the economic successes that President Trump has had. There are foreign policy successes to speak of as well. Just recently we had this peace deal between the United Arab Emirates and Israel. And, of course, this is the president who poked back at China.

What do you believe, having spent all that time at the U.N., to be the biggest threat and how to deal with it from a foreign policy agenda standpoint?

HALEY: Well, I've got to tell you that, you know, one of the biggest surprises when I got to the United Nations was literally how the Obama/Biden administration bought -- wanted to just buy their friends. They wanted to be nice with everyone so that everyone would like us back. And -- and President Trump changed that. He -- he made sure that everyone knew what we were for and what we were against.

I mean our biggest threat hands down is China, but you have to also look at the fact that when we're looking at an Iran deal and there, you know, there's a question about whether they're going to extend the arms embargo, you've got a real problem because this is the number one sponsor of terrorism.

So we need a strong president.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HALEY: We need someone strong on foreign policy and we need our countries to know we're taking notice.

BARTIROMO: Ambassador, stay with us. We're going to slip in a short break. I want to ask you more about that foreign policy when we come right back.

I'm talking with Ambassador Nikki Haley.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are back now with former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and former South Carolina governor, Nikki Haley.

Ambassador, before we went to the break, we were talking about foreign policy. And in your speech last night, you said, Joe Biden is good for Iran, good with ISIS, great for communist China.

I want to ask you about this recent partnership that Iran and China are deepening. I know they do a lot of business already.

How concerned are you that it looks like China is partnering with Iran, not only on the sale of oil, but bigger projects as well? Is this an affront against the United States?

HALEY: We should absolutely be worried about China, but we should be strong against China. You know, what they're trying to do is they're trying to partner with anyone that will weaken America. And so them getting together with the country that's saying death to America is their way of doing that.

But we have put China actually in a very weak spot. Their economy is feeling it. They have seen what's happened now that we hold them accountable on stealing technology. And they're starting to feel it because of everything that we're doing to counter that, whether it's Huawei, whether it's TikTok or anything in between. I think the president has shown that we're onto them and we're not going to let them get away with anything.

But the idea that China is holding hands with Iran is very telling, not just for us, but for our allies around the world.

BARTIROMO: Ambassador, let me ask you, your -- your foreign policy experience is so critical to your leadership. Are we going to see you on the 2024 ticket?

HALEY: Oh, it's too soon to tell any of that right now. Right now I want to get President Trump and Vice President Pence elected.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll leave it there.

Great to see you, Nikki Haley. Thank you so much.

We'll be watching.

HALEY: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Stay with us.

We'll be right back.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH) IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX BUSINESS

AUGUST 25, 2020

SPEAKERS: REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR

[*] MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Ohio Congressman Jim Jordan spoke last night, recounting an emotional time when President Trump comforted his family after his nephew's death. Jordan also slammed Democrats, arguing that they support violent protesters.

Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Look at what's happening in American cities. Cities all run by Democrats. Crime, violence, and mob rule.

Democrats won't let you go to work, but they'll let you riot. And Democrats won't let you go to school, but they'll let you go loot.

President Trump has fought against each of their crazy ideas.

They tried the Russia hoax, the Mueller investigation and the fake impeachment. But in spite of this unbelievable opposition, this president has done what he said he would of do, taxes cut, regulations reduced, economy growing, lowest unemployment in 50 years, out of the Iran deal, embassy in Jerusalem, hostages home from North Korea, a new USMCA agreement and, of course, he's building the wall and rebuilding our economy as we speak.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Ohio Congressman, House Judiciary Committee and House Oversight and Reform Committee member, Jim Jordan.

And, Congressman, it's always a pleasure to see you. Congratulations on the speech last night.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Thank you, Maria. Good to be with you this morning.

BARTIROMO: So tell me what you think is resonating most or what did resonate. You made a -- you made a good point, justification of basically showing what the Republicans are doing in terms of law and order, in terms of insuring that the economy comes back, versus what you're seeing on the other side.

JORDAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Is that what you're goal was?

JORDAN: Well, I think that was part of it. I think really what came through last night, the president said this Sunday night on your network, he talked about the amazing potential of the American people. And I think that was the theme last night.

I mean you think about Nikki Haley's story. You think about Senator Scott's story, his humble beginnings, now a United States senator. You think about Herschel Walker's life. You think about those frontline healthcare workers, frontline first responders that the president talked to there at the White House, the hostages he met with, the amazing potential of the American people and just the positive feel we got last night.

And I meant what I said in my -- in my -- in my speech that the Republican Party is the pro-America party, the institutions, the values, the principles that make our country great. That's what we need to defend. This president is doing that. That's why I think he's going to get reelected.

BARTIROMO: At the same time, the speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi, called the president, as well as the Republicans in Congress, yesterday, domestic enemies, enemies of the state.

Did you see that?

JORDAN: Yes, that -- I mean she has -- she has said a number of things that just make no sense, that are just flat-out wrong. This president is -- I think he's that rare individual who comes to this town and actually does what he told the American people he was going to do. That's what the American people so appreciate about him. And I had that list of things we talked about.

But you think about this -- just take one example. Take putting the embassy in Jerusalem. The -- for -- for as long as I can remember, every single presidential candidate in either party, in both parties, said, if you elect me, I will put the embassy in Jerusalem. Then they get elected and they come up with a million reasons, the swamp gives them tons of reasons why they can't do it. This president did it. And the response you -- and it worked out fine. But -- but the speaker of the House criticizes the president for doing what he told the American people -- that that's how frustrated, that's how -- that's how, you know, the -- the Democrats have been out to get this president, as you know, Maria, since before he was even elected with the whole Trump/Russia investigation.

So it doesn't -- that's nothing new from her. It is so wrong. And I think the American people see through it. And like I said, I think they're going to elect President Trump as the next president.

BARTIROMO: Yes, no, you went through it, first the -- the Russia collusion hoax and then, you know, the Mueller investigation, the impeachment, you called it the fake impeachment. You're right, they have been out to get him and take him down from day one.

Now there's a Postal Service controversy, Congressman. Walk us through this. Postmaster General Louis DeJoy defending his management of the U.S. Postal Service to the House yesterday amid these concerns that his cost-cutting measures are jeopardizing the agency's ability to serve Americans going into a presidential election.

What's at stake here?

JORDAN: Well, what the Democrats are really trying to do, and this is not me saying this, this is "The Wall Street Journal." This is the latest conspiracy theory from the Democrats. But there's $14 billion cash on hand. They've got a $10 billion line of credit. What he's doing on collection boxes and sorting machines is nothing new. In fact, the Obama/Biden administration, between 2011 and 2016 removed 12,000 collection boxes around the country. So he's doing nothing new.

But the Democrats want to create chaos and confusion because they want to count ballots after Election Day. That's what this is about. You saw what happened in New York. One congressional primary, actually the chairwoman of the committee, the sponsor of the Democrats' bill, Caroline Maloney, her election was June 23rd. She wasn't declared the winner until six weeks later.

In the New Jersey primaries, it took four weeks to count the ballots after the primary election date. And, frankly, look -- go back to the Iowa Democrat caucuses. I don't even know -- I don't know if we still know who won -- who won the Democrat caucus for the -- for the presidential race.

So the Democrats want this chaos and confusion because I believe, and I'm convinced, they know President Trump is going to win on Election Day, but they want to keep counting ballots after Election Day.

So that's what this is really about. They want to send out as many live ballots, mail out as many live ballots as they can around this country and then be counting after -- after the election night, after election night's over.

So, that's what this is about. We need to call it for what it is. And -- but they're attacking the post office for the -- for those reasons. And that's what's -- that's what's scary to me. That's why they're getting so fired up.

But in -- again, in spite of all that, the president's going to win. I can just feel -- you can see it in Ohio.

BARTIROMO: But -- but, Congressman --

JORDAN: I mean he won big in Ohio.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JORDAN: And I think it's going to be even bigger this time.

BARTIROMO: So you don't -- you don't buy the polls then because in the polls he's been lagging.

Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Look at what's happening in American cities. Cities all run by Democrats. Crime, violence, and mob rule.

Democrats won't let you go to work, but they'll let you riot. And Democrats won't let you go to school, but they'll let you go loot.

President Trump has fought against each of their crazy ideas.

They tried the Russia hoax, the Mueller investigation and the fake impeachment. But in spite of this unbelievable opposition, this president has done what he said he would of do, taxes cut, regulations reduced, economy growing, lowest unemployment in 50 years, out of the Iran deal, embassy in Jerusalem, hostages home from North Korea, a new USMCA agreement and, of course, he's building the wall and rebuilding our economy as we speak.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Ohio Congressman, House Judiciary Committee and House Oversight and Reform Committee member, Jim Jordan.

And, Congressman, it's always a pleasure to see you. Congratulations on the speech last night.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Thank you, Maria. Good to be with you this morning.

BARTIROMO: So tell me what you think is resonating most or what did resonate. You made a -- you made a good point, justification of basically showing what the Republicans are doing in terms of law and order, in terms of insuring that the economy comes back, versus what you're seeing on the other side.

JORDAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Is that what you're goal was?

JORDAN: Well, I think that was part of it. I think really what came through last night, the president said this Sunday night on your network, he talked about the amazing potential of the American people. And I think that was the theme last night.

I mean you think about Nikki Haley's story. You think about Senator Scott's story, his humble beginnings, now a United States senator. You think about Herschel Walker's life. You think about those frontline healthcare workers, frontline first responders that the president talked to there at the White House, the hostages he met with, the amazing potential of the American people and just the positive feel we got last night.

Did you see that?

So it doesn't -- that's nothing new from her. It is so wrong. And I think the American people see through it. And like I said, I think they're going to elect President Trump as the next president.

But in -- again, in spite of all that, the president's going to win. I can just feel -- you can see it in Ohio.

BARTIROMO: But -- but, Congressman --

JORDAN: I mean he won big in Ohio.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Congressman Jim Jordan, it's great to see you, sir. Thank you.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH) IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX BUSINESS

AUGUST 6, 2020

SPEAKERS: REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH)

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS HOST

[*] STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS HOST: He's going there. He's going there today. And as we've said, he's going to visit the Whirlpool factory.

Joining us now is Congressman Jim Jordan. He's from Ohio. He will be with the president.

First of all, Congressman, why Whirlpool?

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Well, this president has been manufacturing's best friend. And Whirlpool is a company with thousands of employees across our great state and all around the -- all around the country.

And as you mentioned, the trade policies that the president has enacted has benefited not just Whirlpool but all of Ohio manufacturing and, frankly, manufacturing across the country. So this is a great place to visit. It's right in the northern part, north-central part of our great state and in our -- in our district. So we're -- we're happy the president's going to be here and I think he's going to get a tremendous reception.

Remember, Stuart, he won Ohio by 8.5 points in '16. I think he's going to do the same in 2020 and he's going to be re-elected as president of the United States.

VARNEY: Well, that's interesting because, at this moment, in a -- in a latest poll, Biden leads Mr. Trump by only one point in Ohio. And I noticed that today Joe Biden is going on a virtual tour of Ohio, but the president will actually be there in person.

JORDAN: Yes. Yes. No, the president's going to be here. Then he's going to head to Cleveland, talk to some folks there. I mean it's -- it's going to be a great day for our state.

And as I said, Joe Biden can hang out in his basement and he can do his virtual tours and he can keep making all the mistakes he makes every time he speaks. This president's going to get out and about and talk with the American people and remind them of the great economy we had. Remember, before this virus, taxes cut, regulations reduced, economy growing at an unbelievable clip, lowest unemployment in 50 years, wages up. Everything was going great. And, guess what? That great -- the virus hit but the great American comeback has started.

VARNEY: Good (ph).

JORDAN: The numbers you had at the top of your program, the jobs numbers, the market numbers, I mean it's all moving in the right direction. And if we can get Democrat governors to actually let their citizens, let Americans go back to work, you would see this -- you would see us right back to where we were in March. It would happen but for these -- these Democrat governors that don't want to let Americans go back to work.

VARNEY: I've got to get this in. You are the perfect person to talk to about censorship.

JORDAN: Yes. VARNEY: Facebook and Twitter taking down that post from President Trump where he said children were almost immune from the virus. I call it flat-out censorship.

JORDAN: It is.

VARNEY: And I guess you do, too?

JORDAN: No, it is. And why is it always conservatives?

VARNEY: Right.

JORDAN: You never hear about anyone on the left getting censored. It's always conservatives. Here's what Twitter did just a couple weeks ago. They let the leader of Iran, the largest state sponsor of terrorism, put a tweet out that said he will strike a blow against American citizens. That was fine but they censor the president of the United States?

So, look, over the next 80 some days, before this election, we got to call them out every time it happens. And then when President Trump wins re-election and Republicans take back the House, we have to look at the consequences for big tech targeting conservatives.

And there's no other way to say it, Stuart. It's not a hunch. It's not a suspicion.

VARNEY: It's --

JORDAN: Big tech is out to get conservatives.

VARNEY: Absolutely. Absolutely.

JORDAN: And if they're going to continue to do it, there has to be -- there has to be implications and consequences for those actions.

VARNEY: It is incredible to me that the largest, most powerful companies in the world are run by vigorous anti-Trump people from top to bottom. That seems to be the way it is.

JORDAN: Yes.

VARNEY: Congressman, I know you'd love to keep talking about this and so would I, but you know what, we've got to make some money by playing a commercial.

We will see you again, sir. Good luck.

JORDAN: Take care. Thanks, Stuart.

VARNEY: Thank you.

END

Remember, Stuart, he won Ohio by 8.5 points in '16. I think he's going to do the same in 2020 and he's going to be re-elected as president of the United States.

VARNEY: Well, that's interesting because, at this moment, in a -- in a latest poll, Biden leads Mr. Trump by only one point in Ohio. And I noticed that today Joe Biden is going on a virtual tour of Ohio, but the president will actually be there in person.

JORDAN: Yes. Yes. No, the president's going to be here. Then he's going to head to Cleveland, talk to some folks there. I mean it's -- it's going to be a great day for our state.

And as I said, Joe Biden can hang out in his basement and he can do his virtual tours and he can keep making all the mistakes he makes every time he speaks. This president's going to get out and about and talk with the American people and remind them of the great economy we had. Remember, before this virus, taxes cut, regulations reduced, economy growing at an unbelievable clip, lowest unemployment in 50 years, wages up. Everything was going great. And, guess what? That great -- the virus hit but the great American comeback has started.

VARNEY: Good (ph).

JORDAN: The numbers you had at the top of your program, the jobs numbers, the market numbers, I mean it's all moving in the right direction. And if we can get Democrat governors to actually let their citizens, let Americans go back to work, you would see this -- you would see us right back to where we were in March. It would happen but for these -- these Democrat governors that don't want to let Americans go back to work.

VARNEY: I've got to get this in. You are the perfect person to talk to about censorship.

JORDAN: Yes. VARNEY: Facebook and Twitter taking down that post from President Trump where he said children were almost immune from the virus. I call it flat-out censorship.

JORDAN: It is.

VARNEY: And I guess you do, too?

JORDAN: No, it is. And why is it always conservatives?

VARNEY: Right.

JORDAN: You never hear about anyone on the left getting censored. It's always conservatives. Here's what Twitter did just a couple weeks ago. They let the leader of Iran, the largest state sponsor of terrorism, put a tweet out that said he will strike a blow against American citizens. That was fine but they censor the president of the United States?

So, look, over the next 80 some days, before this election, we got to call them out every time it happens. And then when President Trump wins re-election and Republicans take back the House, we have to look at the consequences for big tech targeting conservatives.

And there's no other way to say it, Stuart. It's not a hunch. It's not a suspicion.

VARNEY: It's --

JORDAN: Big tech is out to get conservatives.

VARNEY: Absolutely. Absolutely.

JORDAN: And if they're going to continue to do it, there has to be -- there has to be implications and consequences for those actions.

VARNEY: It is incredible to me that the largest, most powerful companies in the world are run by vigorous anti-Trump people from top to bottom. That seems to be the way it is.

JORDAN: Yes.

VARNEY: Congressman, I know you'd love to keep talking about this and so would I, but you know what, we've got to make some money by playing a commercial.

We will see you again, sir. Good luck.

JORDAN: Take care. Thanks, Stuart.

VARNEY: Thank you.

END

urn:contentItem:60G7-H9H1-F03R-N3VS-00000-00Rep. Jim Jordan SCORCHES Big Tech at Antitrust Hearing: They're 'Out to Get Conservatives'2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:09ZLexisNexisRep. Jim Jordan SCORCHES Big Tech at Antitrust Hearing: They're 'Out to Get Conservatives'Alexander Hall

Jul 29, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) Congressman Jim Jordan (R-OH) raked Big Tech over the coals, saying there's no more denying what can be plainly seen: 'Big Tech is out to get conservatives. That's not a suspicion. That's not a hunch.

That's a fact.'Jordan slammed Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, Apple CEO Tim Cook, Google CEO Sundar Pichai and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg for being openly biased against conservatives and for trying to throttle political opposition as the 2020 election approaches. He observed, '[W]e're 97 days before an election,' and Big Tech is engaged in 'censoring conservatives and trying to impact elections.' He warned, 'If it doesn't end, there have to be consequences.'Jordan summarized at the House Committee on the Judiciary's Antitrust, Commercial, and Administrative Law Subcommittee[1] how Twitter allows the leadership of Iran to use the platform, the very same nation he called the 'largest state sponsor of terrorism.' He remarked on how Twitter allowed Iranian leadership to threaten to 'strike a reciprocal blow' to the U.S. after Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Major General Qasem Soleimani was killed. He then observed that Iranian leadership can use Twitter to 'threaten the citizens of this great country,' but the U.S. president 'gets censored' for declaring that he will not allow violent rioters from building an autonomous zone in Washington, D.C.Jordan even trashed Big Tech across the board for censoring users who contradict the World Health Organization, 'the organization that lied to us, the organization that shilled for China,' he qualified. Jordan juxtaposed how WHO 'can say whatever they want. They can lie for China, they can shill for China,' but 'if you say something against them, you get censored.' WHO, as late as mid-January, told millions of Twitter users[2] that 'Chinese authorities have found no clear evidence of human-to-human transmission' of COVID-19. He mentioned how Twitter reportedly shadowbanned Republicans, including Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL), Rep. Mark Meadows (R-NC), Rep. Devin Nunes (R-CA) and Jordan himself. He said Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey responded by saying, 'Oh, it was just a glitch in our algorithm.'Indeed, this comes at a time when the overwhelming majority[3] of Americans from across the political spectrum are skeptical over Big Tech's unchecked power, a Pew Research Center study found. 'Overall, 72% of U.S. adults say social media companies have too much power and influence in politics today, according to the June 16-22 survey,' Pew's FactTank observed[4] July 22. In addition, about half of Americans surveyed also believe the government should do more to regulate Big Tech companies whose power appears to be unchecked.Conservatives are under attack. Give the House Committee on the Judiciary's Antitrust, Commercial, and Administrative Law Subcommittee a call at 202-225-3951 and demand that Big Tech be held accountable. He observed, “[W]e’re 97 days before an election,” and Big Tech is engaged in “censoring conservatives and trying to impact elections.” He warned, “If it doesn’t end, there have to be consequences.” Jordan summarized at the House Committee on the Judiciary’s Antitrust, Commercial, and Administrative Law Subcommittee how Twitter allows the leadership of Iran to use the platform, the very same nation he called the “largest state sponsor of terrorism.” He remarked on how Twitter allowed Iranian leadership to threaten to “strike a reciprocal blow” to the U.S. after Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Major General Qasem Soleimani was killed. He then observed that Iranian leadership can use Twitter to “threaten the citizens of this great country,” but the U.S. president “gets censored” for declaring that he will not allow violent rioters from building an autonomous zone in Washington, D.C. Jordan even trashed Big Tech across the board for censoring users who contradict the World Health Organization, “the organization that lied to us, the organization that shilled for China,” he qualified. Jordan juxtaposed how WHO “can say whatever they want. They can lie for China, they can shill for China,” but “if you say something against them, you get censored.” WHO, as late as mid-January, told millions of Twitter users that “Chinese authorities have found no clear evidence of human-to-human transmission” of COVID-19. He mentioned how Twitter reportedly shadowbanned Republicans, including Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL), Rep. Mark Meadows (R-NC), Rep. Devin Nunes (R-CA) and Jordan himself. He said Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey responded by saying, “Oh, it was just a glitch in our algorithm.” Indeed, this comes at a time when the overwhelming majority of Americans from across the political spectrum are skeptical over Big Tech’s unchecked power, a Pew Research Center study found. “Overall, 72% of U.S. adults say social media companies have too much power and influence in politics today, according to the June 16-22 survey,” Pew’s FactTank observed July 22. In addition, about half of Americans surveyed also believe the government should do more to regulate Big Tech companies whose power appears to be unchecked. Conservatives are under attack. Give the House Committee on the Judiciary’s Antitrust, Commercial, and Administrative Law Subcommittee a call at 202-225-3951 and demand that Big Tech be held accountable. If you have been censored, contact us at the Media Research Center contact form.

Rep. Joe Barton, R-TX. discusses politics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

REP. JOE BARTON (R), TEXAS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

APRIL 10, 2018

SPEAKERS: REP. JOE BARTON (R), TEXAS

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: What'd You Miss? Amid all the attention on Mark Zuckerberg and Syria, House Speaker Paul Ryan today said he will not seek reelection in November.

We want to welcome Congressman Joe Barton from Capitol Hill. He is a Republican from Texas. He's also a vice chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee which Zuckerberg just testified before. Congressman, thank you so much for joining us this afternoon. I want to start with of course Speaker Ryan's announcement that he will retire. Are you sorry to see him go or are you glad to see him stepped down?

REP. JOE BARTON (R), TEXAS: Well, I'm happy for his family. They'll get to see him a lot more. And that's a good thing. He has teenaged children. I'm sad for the Congress and for the country. Paul Ryan is a good public servant. He has been a good speaker. And he's somebody I consider to be a personal friend. He will be missed.

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: He had challenges though with the diversity, let's call it, of the opinions within the GOP. He's also at times had real tensions with the president too. Who do you think is the best person to replace him? And how is that person pull together all sides of the party once obviously Paul Ryan leaves in January?

BARTON: Well, first of all, Paul Ryan is still speaker. He's going to be speaker the rest of this year. The next Congress will choose a new speaker. Hopefully, it will be a Republican speaker. I'm a Republican. It could be a Democrat. If the Democrats stay for majority, there'll be no lack of candidates. A lot of them, obviously all of them on the Republican side, I know very well. I'm not going to pick a favorite. But, you know, again Paul Ryan has been a very good speaker. And whoever replaces him will have big shoes to fill.

CHATTERLEY: Congressman you said it then, not them. I mean there are a lot of people looking at this and saying this is capitulation by Paul Ryan that he simply doesn't want to be a minority leader after the midterm. Is that what this is?

BARTON: I do not believe so. I think there's every chance that we'll maintain our majority. We passed this big tax cut bill that's improving people's paychecks. Economic growth is not going to be over 3 percent this year. It's a good thing. A lot of companies are reinvesting in America, which is what President Trump promised when he ran for president. We did pass a health care bill through the House. It didn't make it through the Senate. But we are beginning to dismantle Obamacare.

We still have six or seven months left to go. And I think there'll still be things that this Congress does. And I think the voters this fall, well, I will not be on the ballot for the first time in 34 years. I think most voters will choose to send the Republican congressman back to Washington.

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Congressman Barton, obviously, you said, it's -- Paul Ryan is still the speaker, it's going to be a while before the candidates emerge. Regardless of who's specifically it is, what does the next speaker, assuming it's a Republican have to do to unite your caucus?

BARTON: Well, I think Paul Ryan has done a good job of reuniting the Republican conference here in the House. I'm a member of the Freedom Caucus which is the most conservative group. And we've worked with the speaker on health care and taxes and some of the big issues. The next speaker will have to continue that process. We still have to reform our health care system. We've got to address entitlement reform. We've got to reduce spending and entitlements to bring them into the lower than the rate of growth in the economy. That's probably the number one challenge.

And then maintain a strong common defense which this Congress has done. And I hope we address immigration issue. If we don't do it in this Congress which is unlikely, I hope we do it in the next. And the new speaker will have that challenge too.

FU: Congressman, I want to turn now to Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg who testified before your committee this afternoon. And of course, I know you asked about Facebook and centering conservative points of view and also how teens and minors use Facebook. But I wonder whether you get a sense that there's any regulation proposals coming in, if so which ones or what kinds you might support?

BARTON: Well, as Chairman Walden pointed out. This is the first hearing. It's a fact finding hearing. I'm the cofounder with now Senator Ed Markey of Massachusetts, a Democrat of the Congressional Privacy Caucus here on Capitol Hill. I'm still the House co-chairman along with Diana DeGette here in the House.

I think you could put some, for the lack of better term, soft regulations on the -- on protecting people's privacy on the internet. Currently, you can protect your privacy to some extent. But you've really got to work hard at it and you've got to really redefine print of all these user agreements. It should not be that hard.

We could certainly clarify what the default position is on most of these servers and internet providers, the ISPs. We could do that in a bipartisan basis. We could certainly, totally protect the privacy of children. That's what I ask some specific question for Mr. Zuckerberg about. I don't think our younger generation really understands that they have a right to privacy. And we need to reestablish that.

CHATTERLEY: The problem is that, some of the most vocal generations out there, I'm not sure if they necessarily want all that privacy congressman. But I want to ask you because this session was wrapping up. The suggestion was made to other CEOs of this big tech or media however you choose to call them, companies should also come and face Congress. Which CEOs, which companies do you want to be answering similar kind of questions as Facebook because it is a broader question?

BARTON: That will be the decision that Chairman Walden has to make in conjunction with the ranking minority member Mr. Pallone of New Jersey. I'd like to see Google come before the committee. I'd like to see the big telecommunication companies, AT&Ts, Verizon, Sprint, some of those. I would like to see some of the media companies that provide a lot of options in terms of entertainment.

You know, it's not automatic in my mind that all of that data out there is there to be dissected, collated, mined, put together and sold. I still think the individual has the right to decide who gets to see it. And make determination of what cookies are allowed on his or her various internet accounts, things like that.

FU: Congressman Joe Barton, it sounds like it's going to be a busy spring and summer then. Republican of Texas and vice chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, thank you.

BARTON: Thank you.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
