REP. JOE BARTON (R), TEXAS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

APRIL 10, 2018

SPEAKERS: REP. JOE BARTON (R), TEXAS

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: What'd You Miss? Amid all the attention on Mark Zuckerberg and Syria, House Speaker Paul Ryan today said he will not seek reelection in November.

We want to welcome Congressman Joe Barton from Capitol Hill. He is a Republican from Texas. He's also a vice chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee which Zuckerberg just testified before. Congressman, thank you so much for joining us this afternoon. I want to start with of course Speaker Ryan's announcement that he will retire. Are you sorry to see him go or are you glad to see him stepped down?

REP. JOE BARTON (R), TEXAS: Well, I'm happy for his family. They'll get to see him a lot more. And that's a good thing. He has teenaged children. I'm sad for the Congress and for the country. Paul Ryan is a good public servant. He has been a good speaker. And he's somebody I consider to be a personal friend. He will be missed.

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: He had challenges though with the diversity, let's call it, of the opinions within the GOP. He's also at times had real tensions with the president too. Who do you think is the best person to replace him? And how is that person pull together all sides of the party once obviously Paul Ryan leaves in January?

BARTON: Well, first of all, Paul Ryan is still speaker. He's going to be speaker the rest of this year. The next Congress will choose a new speaker. Hopefully, it will be a Republican speaker. I'm a Republican. It could be a Democrat. If the Democrats stay for majority, there'll be no lack of candidates. A lot of them, obviously all of them on the Republican side, I know very well. I'm not going to pick a favorite. But, you know, again Paul Ryan has been a very good speaker. And whoever replaces him will have big shoes to fill.

CHATTERLEY: Congressman you said it then, not them. I mean there are a lot of people looking at this and saying this is capitulation by Paul Ryan that he simply doesn't want to be a minority leader after the midterm. Is that what this is?

BARTON: I do not believe so. I think there's every chance that we'll maintain our majority. We passed this big tax cut bill that's improving people's paychecks. Economic growth is not going to be over 3 percent this year. It's a good thing. A lot of companies are reinvesting in America, which is what President Trump promised when he ran for president. We did pass a health care bill through the House. It didn't make it through the Senate. But we are beginning to dismantle Obamacare.

We still have six or seven months left to go. And I think there'll still be things that this Congress does. And I think the voters this fall, well, I will not be on the ballot for the first time in 34 years. I think most voters will choose to send the Republican congressman back to Washington.

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Congressman Barton, obviously, you said, it's -- Paul Ryan is still the speaker, it's going to be a while before the candidates emerge. Regardless of who's specifically it is, what does the next speaker, assuming it's a Republican have to do to unite your caucus?

BARTON: Well, I think Paul Ryan has done a good job of reuniting the Republican conference here in the House. I'm a member of the Freedom Caucus which is the most conservative group. And we've worked with the speaker on health care and taxes and some of the big issues. The next speaker will have to continue that process. We still have to reform our health care system. We've got to address entitlement reform. We've got to reduce spending and entitlements to bring them into the lower than the rate of growth in the economy. That's probably the number one challenge.

And then maintain a strong common defense which this Congress has done. And I hope we address immigration issue. If we don't do it in this Congress which is unlikely, I hope we do it in the next. And the new speaker will have that challenge too.

FU: Congressman, I want to turn now to Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg who testified before your committee this afternoon. And of course, I know you asked about Facebook and centering conservative points of view and also how teens and minors use Facebook. But I wonder whether you get a sense that there's any regulation proposals coming in, if so which ones or what kinds you might support?

BARTON: Well, as Chairman Walden pointed out. This is the first hearing. It's a fact finding hearing. I'm the cofounder with now Senator Ed Markey of Massachusetts, a Democrat of the Congressional Privacy Caucus here on Capitol Hill. I'm still the House co-chairman along with Diana DeGette here in the House.

I think you could put some, for the lack of better term, soft regulations on the -- on protecting people's privacy on the internet. Currently, you can protect your privacy to some extent. But you've really got to work hard at it and you've got to really redefine print of all these user agreements. It should not be that hard.

We could certainly clarify what the default position is on most of these servers and internet providers, the ISPs. We could do that in a bipartisan basis. We could certainly, totally protect the privacy of children. That's what I ask some specific question for Mr. Zuckerberg about. I don't think our younger generation really understands that they have a right to privacy. And we need to reestablish that.

CHATTERLEY: The problem is that, some of the most vocal generations out there, I'm not sure if they necessarily want all that privacy congressman. But I want to ask you because this session was wrapping up. The suggestion was made to other CEOs of this big tech or media however you choose to call them, companies should also come and face Congress. Which CEOs, which companies do you want to be answering similar kind of questions as Facebook because it is a broader question?

BARTON: That will be the decision that Chairman Walden has to make in conjunction with the ranking minority member Mr. Pallone of New Jersey. I'd like to see Google come before the committee. I'd like to see the big telecommunication companies, AT&Ts, Verizon, Sprint, some of those. I would like to see some of the media companies that provide a lot of options in terms of entertainment.

You know, it's not automatic in my mind that all of that data out there is there to be dissected, collated, mined, put together and sold. I still think the individual has the right to decide who gets to see it. And make determination of what cookies are allowed on his or her various internet accounts, things like that.

FU: Congressman Joe Barton, it sounds like it's going to be a busy spring and summer then. Republican of Texas and vice chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, thank you.

BARTON: Thank you.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5S39-P401-F15W-H2J2-00000-00REP. JOE BARTON, R-TX., IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION2018-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:09ZLexisNexisREP. JOE BARTON, R-TX., IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

April 11, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

REP. JOE BARTON (R), TEXAS

FU: What'd You Miss? Amid all the attention on Mark Zuckerberg and Syria, House Speaker Paul Ryan today said he will not seek reelection in November.

We want to welcome Congressman Joe Barton from Capitol Hill. He is a Republican from Texas. He's also a vice chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee which Zuckerberg just testified before. Congressman, thank you so much for joining us this afternoon. I want to start with of course Speaker Ryan's announcement that he will retire. Are you sorry to see him go or are you glad to see him stepped down?

BARTON: Well, I'm happy for his family. They'll get to see him a lot more. And that's a good thing. He has teenaged children. I'm sad for the Congress and for the country. Paul Ryan is a good public servant. He has been a good speaker. And he's somebody I consider to be a personal friend. He will be missed.

CHATTERLEY: He had challenges though with the diversity, let's call it, of the opinions within the GOP. He's also at times had real tensions with the president too. Who do you think is the best person to replace him? And how is that person pull together all sides of the party once obviously Paul Ryan leaves in January?

BARTON: Well, first of all, Paul Ryan is still speaker. He's going to be speaker the rest of this year. The next Congress will choose a new speaker. Hopefully, it will be a Republican speaker. I'm a Republican. It could be a Democrat. If the Democrats stay for majority, there'll be no lack of candidates. A lot of them, obviously all of them on the Republican side, I know very well. I'm not going to pick a favorite. But, you know, again Paul Ryan has been a very good speaker. And whoever replaces him will have big shoes to fill.

CHATTERLEY: Congressman you said it then, not them. I mean there are a lot of people looking at this and saying this is capitulation by Paul Ryan that he simply doesn't want to be a minority leader after the midterm. Is that what this is?

BARTON: I do not believe so. I think there's every chance that we'll maintain our majority. We passed this big tax cut bill that's improving people's paychecks. Economic growth is not going to be over 3 percent this year. It's a good thing. A lot of companies are reinvesting in America, which is what President Trump promised when he ran for president. We did pass a health care bill through the House. It didn't make it through the Senate. But we are beginning to dismantle Obamacare.

We still have six or seven months left to go. And I think there'll still be things that this Congress does. And I think the voters this fall, well, I will not be on the ballot for the first time in 34 years. I think most voters will choose to send the Republican congressman back to Washington.

WEISENTHAL: Congressman Barton, obviously, you said, it's -- Paul Ryan is still the speaker, it's going to be a while before the candidates emerge. Regardless of who's specifically it is, what does the next speaker, assuming it's a Republican have to do to unite your caucus?

BARTON: Well, I think Paul Ryan has done a good job of reuniting the Republican conference here in the House. I'm a member of the Freedom Caucus which is the most conservative group. And we've worked with the speaker on health care and taxes and some of the big issues. The next speaker will have to continue that process. We still have to reform our health care system. We've got to address entitlement reform. We've got to reduce spending and entitlements to bring them into the lower than the rate of growth in the economy. That's probably the number one challenge.

And then maintain a strong common defense which this Congress has done. And I hope we address immigration issue. If we don't do it in this Congress which is unlikely, I hope we do it in the next. And the new speaker will have that challenge too.

FU: Congressman, I want to turn now to Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg who testified before your committee this afternoon. And of course, I know you asked about Facebook and centering conservative points of view and also how teens and minors use Facebook. But I wonder whether you get a sense that there's any regulation proposals coming in, if so which ones or what kinds you might support?

BARTON: Well, as Chairman Walden pointed out. This is the first hearing. It's a fact finding hearing. I'm the cofounder with now Senator Ed Markey of Massachusetts, a Democrat of the Congressional Privacy Caucus here on Capitol Hill. I'm still the House co-chairman along with Diana DeGette here in the House.

I think you could put some, for the lack of better term, soft regulations on the -- on protecting people's privacy on the internet. Currently, you can protect your privacy to some extent. But you've really got to work hard at it and you've got to really redefine print of all these user agreements. It should not be that hard.

We could certainly clarify what the default position is on most of these servers and internet providers, the ISPs. We could do that in a bipartisan basis. We could certainly, totally protect the privacy of children. That's what I ask some specific question for Mr. Zuckerberg about. I don't think our younger generation really understands that they have a right to privacy. And we need to reestablish that.

CHATTERLEY: The problem is that, some of the most vocal generations out there, I'm not sure if they necessarily want all that privacy congressman. But I want to ask you because this session was wrapping up. The suggestion was made to other CEOs of this big tech or media however you choose to call them, companies should also come and face Congress. Which CEOs, which companies do you want to be answering similar kind of questions as Facebook because it is a broader question?

BARTON: That will be the decision that Chairman Walden has to make in conjunction with the ranking minority member Mr. Pallone of New Jersey. I'd like to see Google come before the committee. I'd like to see the big telecommunication companies, AT&Ts, Verizon, Sprint, some of those. I would like to see some of the media companies that provide a lot of options in terms of entertainment.

You know, it's not automatic in my mind that all of that data out there is there to be dissected, collated, mined, put together and sold. I still think the individual has the right to decide who gets to see it. And make determination of what cookies are allowed on his or her various internet accounts, things like that.

FU: Congressman Joe Barton, it sounds like it's going to be a busy spring and summer then. Republican of Texas and vice chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, thank you.

BARTON: Thank you.

END

Jul 29, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/Delivered by Newstex) Congressman Ken Buck (R-CO) pulled no punches when he demolished Google for enabling Chinese tyranny.During a Congressional Antitrust Hearing[1] hearing, Buck brought the hammer down on Google CEO Sundar Pichai for his company's ties to China. Buck commented on how Google removed itself from the bidding process to work with the American military,[2] but continued to work with China.He remarked that 'Google's stated reason for removing itself from the bidding process is that the U.S. military's project [JEDI] did not align with Google's corporate values and principles.' By contrast, he explained how U.S. Marine General Joseph Dunford Jr.[3] warned that China was 'directly benefiting from Google's work.'Buck said that this made him 'wonder what values Google and communist red China have in common.'

He asked himself: 'Is it that the Chinese Communist party imprisons Uighur Muslims in concentration camps,' or 'could it be that China forces slaves to work in sweatshops?'Perhaps more relevant to Big Tech tactics, he asked if Google's views 'align on the design to suppress free speech in Hong Kong,' or the 'CCP's decision to lie to the world about the COVID-19 pandemic.' He then mentioned Google's embarrassing involvement with Project Dragonfly, a search engine that was being developed for the communist Chinese regime 'to spy on its own people and enforce draconian security laws.'Buck used his Twitter page[4] to retweet footage from the hearing and summarized his questions: 'If Google wants to cozy up to Communist China, Mr. Pichai must answer for the atrocities committed by the CCP.'Do they agree with CCP suppression of free speech in Hong Kong?'Or the imprisonment [sic] Uighur Muslims?'What about China's use of slave labor?' Indeed, this comes at a time when the overwhelming majority[5] of Americans from across the political spectrum are skeptical over Big Tech's unchecked power, a Pew Research Center study found. 'Overall, 72% of U.S. adults say social media companies have too much power and influence in politics today, according to the June 16-22 survey,' Pew's FactTank observed[6] July 22. In addition, about half of Americans surveyed also believe the government should do more to regulate Big Tech companies whose power appears to be unchecked.Conservatives are under attack. During a Congressional Antitrust Hearing hearing, Buck brought the hammer down on Google CEO Sundar Pichai for his company’s ties to China. Buck commented on how Google removed itself from the bidding process to work with the American military, but continued to work with China. In addition, about half of Americans surveyed also believe the government should do more to regulate Big Tech companies whose power appears to be unchecked. Conservatives are under attack. REP. KEN BUCK (R-CO) IS INTERVIEWED ON VARNEY AND CO.

JULY 27, 2020

SPEAKERS: REP. KEN BUCK (R-CO)

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST

[*] VARNEY: Next we have this. What have we got here? OK, there's a car has driven through a crowd of protesters. You can see that. That was in Arura, Colorado, I believe. Another protester was shot. Look, lots of events going on there in Colorado over the weekend.

Congressman Ken Buck, Republican from Colorado, is with us right now.

Look, sir, this is shaping up as a clash between local Democrat authorities and federal authorities. Those are the two sides here. Seems like impossible to bring them together.

BUCK: Well, I think it is very difficult to bring them together. And one thing that I think people have to understand is when -- when folks are protesting peacefully, we've got to respect that distance, we've got to respect their voice. When they commit crimes, it is the job of the police officers, whether they're property crimes or crimes against people, jobs of the police officers to make sure that those folks are arrest and brought to justice.

VARNEY: What's going on here, Congressman? I mean we've pitched battles in the streets all across America and no sign that it's going to end.

BUCK: Yes, I think it's terribly sad. And what's going on is very simple. People do not understand that this is a country where there is free speech. People can exercise that free speech. And we should allow those people to protest.

I know that in -- in Colorado, we had a protest in support of the police and they were, the protesters, the conservatives who were trying to support the police were attacked for doing so. That -- that can't happen in -- in this country.

VARNEY: I just wonder when it's going to end and what the -- what's the politics of this? I mean middle America is looking at what's going on in the cities. They see pitched battles all over the place. Our cities are in flames. What's the politics of this?

BUCK: Well, I think it plays to two sides. On the right, I think people are very frustrated and I think President Trump is gaining quiet support as a result of the anarchists and their tactics. On the left, I think people understand, or appreciate -- wrongfully appreciate the fact that while there are some social issues in this country that need to be addressed, the violence is getting out of hand. And I think while the left appreciates action on important issues, I think they are also frustrated that there is violence.

VARNEY: I want to ask you about the leader of the big tech companies who will be virtually appearing on Capitol Hill later this week. I want to ask your opinion. Do you want to break up these big tech companies? Do you want to tax them some more? Do you want to, in some way, regulate them? Do you want to inhibit the activities of what I call the crown jewels of American business or do you want to just leave them alone? What do you want to do with the big tech in America?

BUCK: Well, I don't want to do any of the above. None of the things that you described are something that I advocate. Congress' role is to create laws and to update laws that apply to these tech companies and can be used by regulators to make sure that there's no anti-competitive behavior. That's the role of Congress. I don't think Congress can walk into this and say, we want to break up these companies or not. Our job is to make sure that laws that are antiquated, laws that don't apply in this situation, are applicable to where technology has -- has gone.

VARNEY: Congressman Ken Buck, Republican, Colorado, thank you for joining us, sir. We appreciate it.

BUCK: Thank you.

VARNEY: Thank you, sir.

END

Facing Criticism Over Pro-Democracy Tweet; Anduril Unveils Drone-Smashing Interceptor UAV; Impeachment Obsession Whistleblower In Focus Despite 2020 Democrat Problems; Streaming Wars Intensify Disney Banning Netflix Ads Across Its NetworksMaria Bartiromo, Blake Burman, Jackie DeAngelis, Todd Piro, Stuart Varney, Brett Larson

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Monday, October 7th. Your top stories right now, 8:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Markets are lower this morning, some uneasiness ahead of the China-U.S. meeting, happening on Thursday, this week, this is the resumption of trade talks, Dow Industrials now indicated, down 60 points, S&P down 7, and the NASDAQ lower by 22.

This after last week's, well, it was a down week, but Friday was a good day. Stocks rallied Friday following the jobs' report, 135,000 jobs added to the economy. The NASDAQ was higher for the week, but Friday's gains were not enough to bring the Dow and the S&P out of negative territory for the week.

Global markets this morning, are mostly higher, take a look at European indices right now, we did have more signs of a slowdown in Europe this morning, we've got the German factory orders number, declining six-tenths of a percent in the month of August, more than expected. Orders from inside Germany were down 2-1/2 percent, 2.6 percent.

FT 100 nonetheless, up 18 points, CAC Quarante in Paris up 9 points, DAX Index in Germany, higher by 26. In Asia overnight, markets in China and Hong Kong closed for the Golden Week holidays, 70 years of Communist rule celebration. Meanwhile, the others were fractionally moving.

The U.S.-China trade tensions are in focus this morning, China, says that it is narrowing the list and the scope of possible issues that it is even willing to discuss, at this week's meeting on Thursday. A look at what could be off the table when both sides meet Thursday in Washington, coming up.

Then, the NBA is under fire this morning from China, Chinese businesses cutting ties with the Houston Rockets after its manager expressed support for Hong Kong's pro-democracy activists, in a tweet, even the NBA is distancing itself from the remarks, prompting backlash from lawmakers, all this as violent protests continue over the weekend, in 18 straight weekends of protesters in Hong Kong.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning, but first, our top story this half an hour, whistleblower controversy continues, the attorney representing the Ukraine whistleblower says another person is coming forward with a complaint against the president. Blake Burman is at the White House this morning, covering the story. Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWS SENIOR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you. That's right. There are now multiple whistleblowers, and one of those whistleblowers is said to have firsthand knowledge of that July 25th phone call between President Trump and the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky.

Attorney Mark Zaid, tweeting out over the weekend, the following, writing "news update: I can confirm this report of a second whistleblower being represented by our legal team. They also made a protective disclosure under the law and cannot be retaliated against. This whistleblower has firsthand knowledge.

The Democratic Congressman Jim Himes, who is the number two Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, contends that these whistleblowers could not sit by idle any longer.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JIM HIMES (D-CT): People around the president, professionals, who are in the Oval Office, who are in the situation room, are watching what is happening, and are finally saying, my God, this cannot happen anymore.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The White House Press Secretary Stephanie Grisham shrugged off reports of another whistleblower, saying in a statement, "It doesn't matter how many people decide to call themselves whistleblowers, about the same telephone call, a call the president already made public, it doesn't change the fact that he has done nothing wrong.

One of the president's top allies on Capitol Hill, Senator Lindsey Graham, saying on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" that he feels the mounting allegations parallel Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court nomination.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC): This is Kavanaugh all over again. It -- does this second whistleblower, if there is one, are they within the intel community? And what is it about the intel community and Trump that is so off base here?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Meantime, Maria, here at the White House, we await a letter from the president, to Nancy Pelosi, that will challenge her to officially hold a vote on an impeachment inquiry. This could happen at some point this week.

The thinking here, Maria, over here at the White House, is that the president is not being afforded all of the legal rights that he would have, if there would be an official impeachment inquiry versus kind of the state of limbo, that everything is in, right now. Maria?

BARTIROMO: All right, Blake, thank you. We will be following that. Blake Burman is at the White House. And joining us right now with more on that is California congressman, House Minority leader, Kevin McCarthy, Leader McCarthy, it's good to see you.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA): Thank you. First time on the new set. It's wonderful.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. And you sent two letters to Speaker Pelosi last week, calling for customary rules and procedures to be established for the impeachment inquiry. I want you to talk about that a bit, because I know that having an inquiry in the intel committee is different than having it in the judiciary committee. Can you explain?

MCCARTHY: Well, first of all, let's think about all the past Congress in modern history, before they go to any impeachment, they have an impeachment inquiry, why? Because it's such an important fact. You are asking to remove -- which democratically, someone was just elected, so you should not take this lightly.

And everybody in America lends their voice to 435 people, so everybody should have a voice, and it sets the rules. So, with Clinton, with Nixon, with the judges, a fair process. Right now, the minority does not have the right to subpoena power. The president's counsel can't be in the room. They moved it from the jurisdiction of having it from judiciary to intel.

So now, they have a hearing, you know who gets to control who gets to come in the room? The Democrats. They tell us how many Republicans are allowed in, how much staff is allowed in. They don't allow us to set witnesses.

BARTIROMO: So, they want to impeach a duly elected president behind closed doors.

MCCARTHY: Exactly. And if you would release the transcripts of the hearings from last week, I think American public would again say, in this facade, this is all about politics. No, what happens is, they released just one or two texts, something that makes them look good, instead of letting all the facts speak.

Nowhere in America would somebody go to a trial without able to have a witness, without able to cross-examine without being able to have any fairness, and that is what Nancy Pelosi is doing. She's going against what Speaker Albert did and what Newt Gingrich did, unheard of --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCCARTHY: -- in the process, and it goes to the fact that this is all political.

BARTIROMO: So, we saw that this last week, because Atkinson was in a hearing behind closed doors. Kurt Volker was at a hearing behind closed doors. And these hearings, you know, little things leak out, I guess, and it -- and I'm hearing that -- the testimony, basically put this whole impeachment, you know, idea, it just busted it because of what Kurt Volker said.

MCCARTHY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: But we don't know because it was closed doors.

MCCARTHY: But very clear when you talk to the members who were in there. There was -- they were very clear about no quid, I mean, stated it, the fact, all of them, and they're good for nine hours. But what we found about the I.G., I think, is very important.

Here we go, another common denominator, Adam Schiff, the man who started out telling us he had proof beyond circumstantial, and put America --

BARTIROMO: It was in plain sight. It was in --

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I don't know why I'm smiling because, you know, first thing you do when you wake up on a Monday morning, you look at the media, and you look at what they're saying about impeachment and whistleblowers and all that stuff, then you got to ignore it and look below that what's really going on in the 2020 campaign. But to me, the Democrat presidential hopefuls are in a mess, a right royal mess.

Joe Biden's got an op-ed in The Washington Post in which he says he is going to beat, "President Trump like a drum." He makes no mention whatsoever of Hunter Biden and the problems that he's got with the conflict of interest.

Then you go on to -- let's see who else we got, Bernie Sanders, God bless him, we wish him well, but he's recovering from a heart attack, and I'm not sure how easily you can fit back into a rigorous campaign. It is true that Elizabeth Warren is gaining ground, she is getting a couple of key states, but we've got newspaper reports this morning that some key donors are balking. They don't want a socialist at the head of the Democrat ticket.

Kamala Harris, she only gets eight percent support among California Democrats, that's her home state. Eight percent support in her home state.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

VARNEY: That's looking like a mess. I'll wrap it up for you, Maria, I don't think they can win and I don't think they're going anymore, and I think impeachment is sucking all the oxygen out of their campaign.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Lindsey Graham on Sunday said to me, it was the most consequential week of the president reelection campaign because of all of the reasons you just mentioned, Stu.

VARNEY: He's right.

BARTIROMO: All right. I know you'll have more about it in 10 minutes. We will see you then.

VARNEY: Sure.

BARTIROMO: "VARNEY & CO." begins top of the hour right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart in about 10 minutes' time.

But first, Disney duals with Netflix, we've got it next. It us banning Netflix ads from all of its networks. We'll break down the battle of the media giants right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, it is getting tough. The streaming wars are hitting fever pitch now. Disney is reportedly banning all Netflix ads across all of its networks.

Joining us right now is FOX News Headlines 24/7 morning anchor, Brett Larson. Brett, good to see you.

BRETT LARSON, FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7 ANCHOR: Yes. Good to see you, guys. It is -- this may be the first shot across the bow in the golden age if streaming wars and that's what I'm calling it.

Over the next of couple months, we're going to have dix to choose from, Disney+, Comcast Peacock, Apple+, HBO, and we already Netflix and Hulu. Netflix is, of course, the 800-pound gorilla. They have over a hundred million subscribers worldwide and they're seen as the largest target for all of these competing services.

What we've already seen since Disney+ announced that they're going be launching a streaming service, a lot of content is slowly being yanked off of Netflix, a lot of the content that Disney owns. Comcast did the same thing that, you know, everybody's very concerned. The Office is leaving Netflix because it's going to go the, I think Comcast is calling it Peacock, that's their streaming service.

So this is going to be interesting. And now Disney's saying, "We're not going to run advertisements for Netflix. Odd because they are running advertising for other streaming services, but as Disney says, Netflix doesn't run any advertising, which his true. Sometimes, the advertising is written into the show so it feels like it's part of the content and it's not like a in-your-face advertisement.

So this is the first salvo in the -- in the streaming wars and pretty soon --

BARTIROMO: But these two are the ones to beat, right? I mean where's Amazon on this?

LARSON: Amazon's also in the picture so I guess that would be seven because Amazon has their prime video, which just won a bunch of awards. It was kind of interesting Emmys that all these streaming platforms and cable networks are winning the awards and not the broadcast networks.

Plus, you've got -- you've got CBS All Access, you've got FoxFast. I mean there's all kinds of --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LARSON: There's all these people waiting to take your money every month to provide you with content and it used to be great because Netflix had everything, you pay one fee, that was easy, Brett, you know. Now it's like too easy.

MARTIN: It's too overwhelming, isn't it?

BARTIROMO: A lot. A lot of passwords.

MARTIN: I mean, yes, a lot -- a lot of passwords, a lot of -- a lot of payments and --

BARTIROMO: A lot of passwords. I hate that.

MARTIN: Yes.

LARSON: And how are consumers going to respond with eight or nine options on the table?

MARTIN: I don't know, man.

LARSON: Are we going to -- are we going to subscribe to all of them, are you going to subscribe to half and then your sisters are going to subscribe to half and you're going to share passwords, which you shouldn't do?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LARSON: I mean like that's --

MARTIN: Oh, wait. Nice idea, wait. Yes, I'll do that at home.

LARSON: Like that -- what's going to happen here in the -- everybody's going to be fighting for our eyeballs.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's true. All right. We will leave it there. Brett, good to see you.

LARSON: Thank for having me.

BARTIROMO: Thank you. Brett Larson. Catch Brett every morning on FOX News Headlines 24/7, SiriusXM radio Channel 115. Still ahead, final thoughts from this all-star panel. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts right now. Jack Brewer.

JACK BREWER, CEO, THE BREWER GROUP: I just got back from CHESTER, P.A. We had four killings in the last three weeks. These kids I got to go to school each day, being in the neighborhoods where folks are getting shot. We cover all of these mass shooting for some time we forget about our inner cities that are being ripped up with all this gun violence. And so all I say is just let's focus on Americans, Americans first.

BARTIROMO: Right.

Jack, you're a real-life super hero, man. Thanks for all you do. Appreciate it. Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Take it away, Maria.

MARTIN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes, all right. Thank you. (INAUDIBLE) at a time.

MARTIN: (INAUDIBLE) on Jack. There we go.

BARTIROMO: That's what happens when you have a phenomenal panel.

BREWER: That's right.

BARTIROMO: Have a great day, everybody. "VARNEY & CO." begins right now. Stu, take it away.

VARNEY: All right. Good morning, Maria.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA) IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX BUSINESS

SEPTEMBER 19, 2019

SPEAKERS: REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR

[*] MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Joining me right now is California congressman, the House minority leader, Kevin McCarthy.

Leader McCarthy, it's always a pleasure.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA): Well, thank you. Thanks for coming to Washington. We appreciate it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, thank you so much. I'm happy to see you again.

USMCA, what are the chances that she brings to it the floor, Nancy Pelosi?

MCCARTHY: I would say today it's 60/40 because it's all up to here. If it came to the floor, it would pass. But what -- what I believe when I say her is Speaker Nancy Pelosi. She has all the power to bring the bill up.

But what we're talking about is negotiations with China. Just a month ago China is no longer a top trader. Mexico's our number one. Canada is number two. If the USMCA would pass, and Mexico passed it months ago, we're about almost a year since all the three leaders signed the agreement, Canada is waiting us on. If we pass that prior to getting into the negotiations with China, we're only stronger.

Think about it, our top two traders getting agreement with them, it makes us stronger in negotiations with China. So thinking of the speaker, Nancy Pelosi, she should bring this up to make America stronger.

BARTIROMO: I just want to point out that we have called Speaker Pelosi, as well as several other Democratic lawmakers to join us to talk about USMCA, and that includes Nancy Pelosi, Chuck Schumer, Congressman Clyburn, Hoyer, Durbin, Sanders, Cummings, Baldwin, as well as Tom Perez, the head of the Democratic Party. None of them would agree to join us this morning. We wanted to do an entire show focused just on USMCA to get their side of the story in terms of why it's not being brought to the floor. They declined.

They want changes. Debbie Dingell was sitting in that seat just a few minutes ago and she said, look, there's not an enforcement that I'm believing in that actually will ensure that U.S. workers are going to make more than $1.50 an hour. She wants to make sure that's in there.

MCCARTHY: Look, the president makes the protection for America works inside this agreement. You have NAFTA today. What the president saw with NAFTA was jobs were leaving America. Jobs will actually come back to America. This is modernizing NAFTA and giving better protections to American workers.

The one thing I would tell you, I've been in meetings where -- where the Prime Minister of Canada is sitting there, Trudeau. They raise these same issues. Trudeau will tell you, I raised it too. We got the agreement inside -- inside USMCA.

So I don't know why we're holding. We should have done this prior to the departure in summer. The real critical time is now because if we're having negotiations with China, if China is going to have their 70th anniversary, then see the president in November, this is the moment in time we should be stronger in those negotiations.

BARTIROMO: Secretary Purdue said, look, if we can't get this done, it's anybody's guess if we can get anything else done in terms of other trade deals.

MCCARTHY: I don't think if this -- if this does not get done by the -- by Thanksgiving, it won't get done. And then the decision will have been made, by the speaker, that it was a political decision, not about the country. It would -- concern about tearing the president down instead of building America up. Because everyone will tell you, at the minimum, 180,000 more jobs. Our GDP goes up. We're stronger. We're stronger in the negotiations.

So I don't understand who out there is saying no to this. I don't hear speaker saying she's against it. She says she can't to get to a yes. The timing of waiting only makes it harder.

BARTIROMO: When you say we want to get to a "yes," I mean, look, we all remember the picture of the president there with the head of Mexico, the head of China (ph), signing on the dotted line.

MCCARTHY: Almost a year ago.

BARTIROMO: They already agreed to it. So when -- when you saying we're going to get to this, do -- are you saying that there's a chance that this can be opened up and then they have to agree to it again? I mean they already agreed to what's on paper.

MCCARTHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So how are we getting to this?

MCCARTHY: And Mexico has already passed it. Canada is waiting. They'll call their session back in to pass it. They're only waiting on America.

So it's almost like the entire world is waiting for the speaker. The Senate, the House, Mexico, Canada, China. China is probably going to want to negotiating before we get this done.

BARTIROMO: Do you think this is going to add to economic growth should it pass --

MCCARTHY: Here's what I think --

BARTIROMO: Because I've got to tell you, global growth is hitting a dictated low amid the U.S.-China trade war according to the OECD. The global economy set to grow at the slowest pace since the financial crises with business investment and trade hampered by this escalating trade feud with China.

That doesn't sound like a booming economy.

MCCARTHY: It is a booming economy. There's more -- there are more jobs being offered today than people actually looking for jobs. You want a little boost in the economy, pass USMCA because the uncertainty of sitting back, the investment of going, and every economic -- economist will tell you, you'll get more jobs and the -- America will be stronger.

BARTIROMO: I want to ask you about our cities, because I know this is important to you as well. I mean you've got New York, where Rikers Island is about to close. There's going to be an enormous number of inmates being let out. Crime is increasing in New York. In San Francisco, there's actually a digital poop map. In L.A. there is homelessness.

And you -- you -- you mentioned to me the other day about medieval diseases coming back in Los Angeles. What --

MCCARTHY: Typhus. Typhus, that you have not seen in years, it moves by infected fleas and rats. Now the rats have come back so far in Los Angeles, you know what happened, city workers have contracted typhus. It's horrendous. And this is --

BARTIROMO: Why? Why?

MCCARTHY: Democratic policy. Prop 47. Prop 57. They decriminalized heroin, cocaine and others. They released people from prison with no training or going on where else (ph), so they've gone on to our streets. Then you have the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals saying you can't remove somebody and give them help unless you have a bed for them. Then they go through and say, you can't even remove them, you've got to give them a three-day notice just because they set up a tent somewhere.

BARTIROMO: Ah. Oh, my gosh.

MCCARTHY: This is the Democratic policies coming to roost in California. And what's even worse in California, they made it so unaffordable. They made it so expensive to live that it's causing it was well. These are drugs, mental illness, and they're not getting the help they need.

And, you know what the governor of California is saying? I'll give free health care to anyone who's illegal wanting to come to America.

BARTIROMO: Wow. I got to move on to a few other things because I want to get your take on the Mideast tensions. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo calling the Saudi oil attack an act of war as signs point to Iran being responsible. The president announced that the U.S. will increase sanctions on Iran, says that he has many options.

What are these options, Congressman?

MCCARTHY: Well, the president, at any given time like this, he will -- he will look at economic options, military options, he can move military assets into the region, which he has done already, which I think was one of the smartest moves he's done because it's actually caused, when you look at what Iran was trying to do earlier and the threats they were making, put us in a position to stop any of that.

But, Iran, this isn't a first action. They are the bad actors. This is why you never want them to have a nuclear weapon. This is why President Trump is correct saying you've got to get out of that agreement. And this is why the rest of the world should join with us and put the pressure on Iran to come back to the table.

BARTIROMO: Do you feel like we do have allies in the rest of the world against that -- Iran?

MCCARTHY: Yes, but I feel our European allies are being weak in this -- in this part --

BARTIROMO: They're still doing business with Iran.

MCCARTHY: Yes. I would not do business with Iran anymore. They fund the terrorists around the world based upon the money we provided them in that last agreement, which was a mistake by all means. We never got to vote on it. It was not a treaty. And this -- and that -- that agreement allows them to have a nuclear weapon at the end of the agreement in 10 years.

BARTIROMO: All right, a couple more issues to got to get to.

I want to ask you about technology. Mark Zuckerberg in town. But also investigate the investigators. Inspector general, Michael Horowitz, telling a congressional panel yesterday he is willing to look into, quote, irregularities from former FBI Director Jim Comey. He also said that he did refer Comey for criminal prosecution but the DOJ turned it down.

Are we going to see accountability for what now most people understand took place in 2016, that they tried to frame then candidate Donald Trump and then President Donald Trump?

MCCARTHY: What is see coming out of the attorney general, yes, he's being very fair, walking it through. What I'm not seeing in the Judiciary Committee by Chairman Nadler is, no. In a normal Congress, after an inspector general gives a report about the DOJ, you would call them in as members of Congress and both sides of the aisle go through that investigation, ask them what they found, but Nadler will not bring that forward.

Nadler's not talking about that. He's not working anything on the border. He's not working on tech. All he's doing is having this imaginary impeachment, which the own speaker he's fighting with.

BARTIROMO: Are you going to see legislation about border? I mean I know Mexico and Guatemala has helped the U.S. and the numbers are down. But is Congress going to do anything about the loopholes that remain around immigration and the border?

MCCARTHY: We have bills introduced. But, again, it comes through the committee of Chairman Nadler. And the only thing he said he wanted to mainly do to become chairman is impeachment. And that's all he's focused on. He's not doing the work that the American public asked him to do.

BARTIROMO: Oh, you're making a lot of comments about the Democrats. Are you going to be able to get the House majority back in 2020?

MCCARTHY: Oh, yes. We just won two races in North Carolina simply by that increase of where we were. We won the -- we won North Caroline Nine in 2018 by 900 votes. We just won it by 4,100. Just that 2 percent --

BARTIROMO: What about all these retirements, Congressman?

MCCARTHY: I'm not worried about the retirements, because the only retirement I worry about is Will Hurd. That's the only person that's sitting in a seat that Hillary carried. There's only two more. These other retirements are Republican seats. You know what it is? It's about as revolution. There's new faces.

You look at Westley Hunt in Houston, graduate of West Point, flew Apaches for ten years and running. This is an ability to change the face of the Republican Party to look like the rest of America and have the leadership of those who want to join with this president who wants to put America first.

BARTIROMO: And you're going to be calling out all these policies, like you -- like you just did in terms of the cities in our country I guess.

Let me ask you about big tech on The Hill.

MCCARTHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: FaceBook founder CEO Mark Zuckerberg in Washington this week to pitch his vision of moderate Internet regulation. He had a dinner meeting last night with a group of lawmakers to help boost the company's image. Your reaction and what should be done with big tech?

MCCARTHY: Well, we've got to make sure with big tech that we have protection. Our own privacy. I believe in private property. Why don't we add private property to our privacy. We should know whatever big tech is gaining from us, from our own knowledge, but we should actually -- if they monetize it, we should be actually paid for it. We should be able to move it. We should be able to delete it.

BARTIROMO: Or at least know where this is going. I mean if you're using my profile to get advertising, I want to know about it.

MCCARTHY: Are they reading my e-mails. Are they using -- you should know it. You should be able to delete it. And you should be able to move it.

But, you know what committee this comes through, Judiciary Committee. Is Nadler doing anything about it? No. He's only focusing on imaginary impeachment.

Immigration, tech, our privacy, inspector general with the problems happening at DOJ, none of that is happening in Judiciary Committee. All Nadler is doing -- that's why Nadler -- I've even had Democrats come to me and tell me, they wonder if he should stay chairman. I don't know if he could stay chairman based upon the actions of what he's doing today.

BARTIROMO: Well, are you calling for him to step down as chairman of Judiciary?

MCCARTHY: If he continues to not act on these issues, why is he in that position? The Democrats did their own poll and asked the American public about impeachment. Only 10 percent said you should worry about it. You know what this poll also said, they could not name one thing that this new Democrat majority has accomplished legislatively, but 54 percent of them could tell you they're only they're doing is investigation. Something the public doesn't -- isn't interested in.

BARTIROMO: Some people think he's worried about his challenger.

MCCARTHY: It's about his primary.

BARTIROMO: Yes, his primary challenger.

Congressman, a lot -- a lot discussed today. We sure appreciate your time.

MCCARTHY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Congressman Kevin McCarthy.

urn:contentItem:5X38-CJD1-JDPT-T035-00000-00REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA) IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX BUSINESS2019-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:10ZLexisNexisREP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA) IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX BUSINESS

September 19, 2019

NEWS PROGRAM

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Joining me right now is California congressman, the House minority leader, Kevin McCarthy.

Leader McCarthy, it's always a pleasure.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA): Well, thank you. Thanks for coming to Washington. We appreciate it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, thank you so much. I'm happy to see you again.

USMCA, what are the chances that she brings to it the floor, Nancy Pelosi?

MCCARTHY: I would say today it's 60/40 because it's all up to here. If it came to the floor, it would pass. But what -- what I believe when I say her is Speaker Nancy Pelosi. She has all the power to bring the bill up.

But what we're talking about is negotiations with China. Just a month ago China is no longer a top trader. Mexico's our number one. Canada is number two. If the USMCA would pass, and Mexico passed it months ago, we're about almost a year since all the three leaders signed the agreement, Canada is waiting us on. If we pass that prior to getting into the negotiations with China, we're only stronger.

Think about it, our top two traders getting agreement with them, it makes us stronger in negotiations with China. So thinking of the speaker, Nancy Pelosi, she should bring this up to make America stronger.

BARTIROMO: I just want to point out that we have called Speaker Pelosi, as well as several other Democratic lawmakers to join us to talk about USMCA, and that includes Nancy Pelosi, Chuck Schumer, Congressman Clyburn, Hoyer, Durbin, Sanders, Cummings, Baldwin, as well as Tom Perez, the head of the Democratic Party. None of them would agree to join us this morning. We wanted to do an entire show focused just on USMCA to get their side of the story in terms of why it's not being brought to the floor. They declined.

They want changes. Debbie Dingell was sitting in that seat just a few minutes ago and she said, look, there's not an enforcement that I'm believing in that actually will ensure that U.S. workers are going to make more than $1.50 an hour. She wants to make sure that's in there.

MCCARTHY: Look, the president makes the protection for America works inside this agreement. You have NAFTA today. What the president saw with NAFTA was jobs were leaving America. Jobs will actually come back to America. This is modernizing NAFTA and giving better protections to American workers.

The one thing I would tell you, I've been in meetings where -- where the Prime Minister of Canada is sitting there, Trudeau. They raise these same issues. Trudeau will tell you, I raised it too. We got the agreement inside -- inside USMCA.

So I don't know why we're holding. We should have done this prior to the departure in summer. The real critical time is now because if we're having negotiations with China, if China is going to have their 70th anniversary, then see the president in November, this is the moment in time we should be stronger in those negotiations.

BARTIROMO: Secretary Purdue said, look, if we can't get this done, it's anybody's guess if we can get anything else done in terms of other trade deals.

MCCARTHY: I don't think if this -- if this does not get done by the -- by Thanksgiving, it won't get done. And then the decision will have been made, by the speaker, that it was a political decision, not about the country. It would -- concern about tearing the president down instead of building America up. Because everyone will tell you, at the minimum, 180,000 more jobs. Our GDP goes up. We're stronger. We're stronger in the negotiations.

So I don't understand who out there is saying no to this. I don't hear speaker saying she's against it. She says she can't to get to a yes. The timing of waiting only makes it harder.

BARTIROMO: When you say we want to get to a "yes," I mean, look, we all remember the picture of the president there with the head of Mexico, the head of China (ph), signing on the dotted line.

MCCARTHY: Almost a year ago.

BARTIROMO: They already agreed to it. So when -- when you saying we're going to get to this, do -- are you saying that there's a chance that this can be opened up and then they have to agree to it again? I mean they already agreed to what's on paper.

MCCARTHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So how are we getting to this?

MCCARTHY: And Mexico has already passed it. Canada is waiting. They'll call their session back in to pass it. They're only waiting on America.

So it's almost like the entire world is waiting for the speaker. The Senate, the House, Mexico, Canada, China. China is probably going to want to negotiating before we get this done.

BARTIROMO: Do you think this is going to add to economic growth should it pass --

MCCARTHY: Here's what I think --

BARTIROMO: Because I've got to tell you, global growth is hitting a dictated low amid the U.S.-China trade war according to the OECD. The global economy set to grow at the slowest pace since the financial crises with business investment and trade hampered by this escalating trade feud with China.

That doesn't sound like a booming economy.

MCCARTHY: It is a booming economy. There's more -- there are more jobs being offered today than people actually looking for jobs. You want a little boost in the economy, pass USMCA because the uncertainty of sitting back, the investment of going, and every economic -- economist will tell you, you'll get more jobs and the -- America will be stronger.

BARTIROMO: I want to ask you about our cities, because I know this is important to you as well. I mean you've got New York, where Rikers Island is about to close. There's going to be an enormous number of inmates being let out. Crime is increasing in New York. In San Francisco, there's actually a digital poop map. In L.A. there is homelessness.

And you -- you -- you mentioned to me the other day about medieval diseases coming back in Los Angeles. What --

MCCARTHY: Typhus. Typhus, that you have not seen in years, it moves by infected fleas and rats. Now the rats have come back so far in Los Angeles, you know what happened, city workers have contracted typhus. It's horrendous. And this is --

BARTIROMO: Why? Why?

MCCARTHY: Democratic policy. Prop 47. Prop 57. They decriminalized heroin, cocaine and others. They released people from prison with no training or going on where else (ph), so they've gone on to our streets. Then you have the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals saying you can't remove somebody and give them help unless you have a bed for them. Then they go through and say, you can't even remove them, you've got to give them a three-day notice just because they set up a tent somewhere.

BARTIROMO: Ah. Oh, my gosh.

MCCARTHY: This is the Democratic policies coming to roost in California. And what's even worse in California, they made it so unaffordable. They made it so expensive to live that it's causing it was well. These are drugs, mental illness, and they're not getting the help they need.

And, you know what the governor of California is saying? I'll give free health care to anyone who's illegal wanting to come to America.

BARTIROMO: Wow. I got to move on to a few other things because I want to get your take on the Mideast tensions. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo calling the Saudi oil attack an act of war as signs point to Iran being responsible. The president announced that the U.S. will increase sanctions on Iran, says that he has many options.

What are these options, Congressman?

MCCARTHY: Well, the president, at any given time like this, he will -- he will look at economic options, military options, he can move military assets into the region, which he has done already, which I think was one of the smartest moves he's done because it's actually caused, when you look at what Iran was trying to do earlier and the threats they were making, put us in a position to stop any of that.

But, Iran, this isn't a first action. They are the bad actors. This is why you never want them to have a nuclear weapon. This is why President Trump is correct saying you've got to get out of that agreement. And this is why the rest of the world should join with us and put the pressure on Iran to come back to the table.

BARTIROMO: Do you feel like we do have allies in the rest of the world against that -- Iran?

MCCARTHY: Yes, but I feel our European allies are being weak in this -- in this part --

BARTIROMO: They're still doing business with Iran.

MCCARTHY: Yes. I would not do business with Iran anymore. They fund the terrorists around the world based upon the money we provided them in that last agreement, which was a mistake by all means. We never got to vote on it. It was not a treaty. And this -- and that -- that agreement allows them to have a nuclear weapon at the end of the agreement in 10 years.

BARTIROMO: All right, a couple more issues to got to get to.

I want to ask you about technology. Mark Zuckerberg in town. But also investigate the investigators. Inspector general, Michael Horowitz, telling a congressional panel yesterday he is willing to look into, quote, irregularities from former FBI Director Jim Comey. He also said that he did refer Comey for criminal prosecution but the DOJ turned it down.

Are we going to see accountability for what now most people understand took place in 2016, that they tried to frame then candidate Donald Trump and then President Donald Trump?

MCCARTHY: What is see coming out of the attorney general, yes, he's being very fair, walking it through. What I'm not seeing in the Judiciary Committee by Chairman Nadler is, no. In a normal Congress, after an inspector general gives a report about the DOJ, you would call them in as members of Congress and both sides of the aisle go through that investigation, ask them what they found, but Nadler will not bring that forward.

Nadler's not talking about that. He's not working anything on the border. He's not working on tech. All he's doing is having this imaginary impeachment, which the own speaker he's fighting with.

BARTIROMO: Are you going to see legislation about border? I mean I know Mexico and Guatemala has helped the U.S. and the numbers are down. But is Congress going to do anything about the loopholes that remain around immigration and the border?

MCCARTHY: We have bills introduced. But, again, it comes through the committee of Chairman Nadler. And the only thing he said he wanted to mainly do to become chairman is impeachment. And that's all he's focused on. He's not doing the work that the American public asked him to do.

BARTIROMO: Oh, you're making a lot of comments about the Democrats. Are you going to be able to get the House majority back in 2020?

MCCARTHY: Oh, yes. We just won two races in North Carolina simply by that increase of where we were. We won the -- we won North Caroline Nine in 2018 by 900 votes. We just won it by 4,100. Just that 2 percent --

BARTIROMO: What about all these retirements, Congressman?

MCCARTHY: I'm not worried about the retirements, because the only retirement I worry about is Will Hurd. That's the only person that's sitting in a seat that Hillary carried. There's only two more. These other retirements are Republican seats. You know what it is? It's about as revolution. There's new faces.

You look at Westley Hunt in Houston, graduate of West Point, flew Apaches for ten years and running. This is an ability to change the face of the Republican Party to look like the rest of America and have the leadership of those who want to join with this president who wants to put America first.

BARTIROMO: And you're going to be calling out all these policies, like you -- like you just did in terms of the cities in our country I guess.

Let me ask you about big tech on The Hill.

MCCARTHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: FaceBook founder CEO Mark Zuckerberg in Washington this week to pitch his vision of moderate Internet regulation. He had a dinner meeting last night with a group of lawmakers to help boost the company's image. Your reaction and what should be done with big tech?

MCCARTHY: Well, we've got to make sure with big tech that we have protection. Our own privacy. I believe in private property. Why don't we add private property to our privacy. We should know whatever big tech is gaining from us, from our own knowledge, but we should actually -- if they monetize it, we should be actually paid for it. We should be able to move it. We should be able to delete it.

BARTIROMO: Or at least know where this is going. I mean if you're using my profile to get advertising, I want to know about it.

MCCARTHY: Are they reading my e-mails. Are they using -- you should know it. You should be able to delete it. And you should be able to move it.

But, you know what committee this comes through, Judiciary Committee. Is Nadler doing anything about it? No. He's only focusing on imaginary impeachment.

Immigration, tech, our privacy, inspector general with the problems happening at DOJ, none of that is happening in Judiciary Committee. All Nadler is doing -- that's why Nadler -- I've even had Democrats come to me and tell me, they wonder if he should stay chairman. I don't know if he could stay chairman based upon the actions of what he's doing today.

BARTIROMO: Well, are you calling for him to step down as chairman of Judiciary?

MCCARTHY: If he continues to not act on these issues, why is he in that position? The Democrats did their own poll and asked the American public about impeachment. Only 10 percent said you should worry about it. You know what this poll also said, they could not name one thing that this new Democrat majority has accomplished legislatively, but 54 percent of them could tell you they're only they're doing is investigation. Something the public doesn't -- isn't interested in.

BARTIROMO: Some people think he's worried about his challenger.

MCCARTHY: It's about his primary.

BARTIROMO: Yes, his primary challenger.

Congressman, a lot -- a lot discussed today. We sure appreciate your time.

MCCARTHY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Congressman Kevin McCarthy.

END

Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) on USMCA, Iran, Jim Comey and Big Tech; Fred Cuts Rates2019-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:10ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTKevin McCarthy, Michael Kantrowitz, Jon Hilsenrath, Byron YorkNEWSInternational091903cb.231Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) on USMCA, Iran, Jim Comey and Big Tech; Fred Cuts RatesMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Dagen McDowell, Gerri Willis

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and I'm coming to you this morning live from Washington, D.C. It is Thursday, September 19th.

Your top stories right now just before 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Back to the negotiating table on China trade. Deputy level talks are getting underway later today here in Washington. This coming as the USMCA bill hangs in the balance. More from my "First on Fox" interview with Vice President Mike Pence coming up.

The Federal Reserve cut interest rates yesterday by a quarter point. That was not enough for President Trump. He slammed Fed Chair Jay Powell, saying that he has no guts.

Markets this morning are under pressure. Futures indicating a decline at the start of trading. We are well off of the lows of the morning. The Dow Industrials right now down 43 points, the S&P is down four, and the Nasdaq lower by 19. This after markets finished the day little changed yesterday, although by the close the DowIndustrials were up 36 points. The S&P was up one and the Nasdaq was lower by 8 points.

Global markets this morning look like this. European indices higher across the board. Take a look. The FT 100's up 45. The CAC quarante in Paris is up 28. And the DAX index in Germany is up 34.

Last hour, the Bank of England announced it is leaving its interest rate unchanged at three quarters of one point.

In Asia overnight, markets finished mixed. Take a look. The Bank of Japan also announcing it's holding interest rates steady. It did, however, express concern over the global economy. And, of course, today's report is that the OECD countries are saying global growth is going to hit a decade low amid the U.S.-China trade war.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning.

But, first, our top story this half an hour. This hour, rather, President Trump is pushing lawmakers to bring the USMCA trade deal to the House floor. Democrats delaying the vote. I spoke about it with the vice president, Mike Pence, during my "First on Fox" interview yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: When we have Democrats on, they talk about the risk of American workers being compared to Mexican workers who might be making $1.50 an hour.

What is the guarantee that American workers are going to be making $16 an hour and won't be competing with a lower wage in Mexico?

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I watched President Trump drive a hard bargain. And all along the way, whether it was American businesses, manufacturing, automotive, whether it was American agricultural, especially dairy, this president demand that this trade deal really put American workers in the city and on the farm first. And the negotiations that we've been conducting with Democrats, in good faith on Capitol Hill, has been about the implementing legislation that will allow for accountability and enforcement of this trade agreement.

BARTIROMO: All of this as U.S.-China trade talks are picking up today in Washington.

Joining me right now is California congressman, the House minority leader, Kevin McCarthy.

Leader McCarthy, it's always a pleasure.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA): Well, thank you. Thanks for coming to Washington. We appreciate it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, thank you so much. I'm happy to see you again.

USMCA, what are the chances that she brings to it the floor, Nancy Pelosi?

MCCARTHY: I would say today it's 60/40 because it's all up to here. If it came to the floor, it would pass. But what -- what I believe when I say her is Speaker Nancy Pelosi. She has all the power to bring the bill up.

But what we're talking about is negotiations with China. Just a month ago China is no longer a top trader. Mexico's our number one. Canada is number two. If the USMCA would pass, and Mexico passed it months ago, we're about almost a year since all the three leaders signed the agreement, Canada is waiting us on. If we pass that prior to getting into the negotiations with China, we're only stronger.

Think about it, our top two traders getting agreement with them, it makes us stronger in negotiations with China. So thinking of the speaker, Nancy Pelosi, she should bring this up to make America stronger.

BARTIROMO: I just want to point out that we have called Speaker Pelosi, as well as several other Democratic lawmakers to join us to talk about USMCA, and that includes Nancy Pelosi, Chuck Schumer, Congressman Clyburn, Hoyer, Durbin, Sanders, Cummings, Baldwin, as well as Tom Perez, the head of the Democratic Party. None of them would agree to join us this morning. We wanted to do an entire show focused just on USMCA to get their side of the story in terms of why it's not being brought to the floor. They declined.

They want changes. Debbie Dingell was sitting in that seat just a few minutes ago and she said, look, there's not an enforcement that I'm believing in that actually will ensure that U.S. workers are going to make more than $1.50 an hour. She wants to make sure that's in there.

MCCARTHY: Look, the president makes the protection for America works inside this agreement. You have NAFTA today. What the president saw with NAFTA was jobs were leaving America. Jobs will actually come back to America. This is modernizing NAFTA and giving better protections to American workers.

The one thing I would tell you, I've been in meetings where -- where the Prime Minister of Canada is sitting there, Trudeau. They raise these same issues. Trudeau will tell you, I raised it too. We got the agreement inside -- inside USMCA.

So I don't know why we're holding. We should have done this prior to the departure in summer. The real critical time is now because if we're having negotiations with China, if China is going to have their 70th anniversary, then see the president in November, this is the moment in time we should be stronger in those negotiations.

BARTIROMO: Secretary Purdue said, look, if we can't get this done, it's anybody's guess if we can get anything else done in terms of other trade deals.

MCCARTHY: I don't think if this -- if this does not get done by the -- by Thanksgiving, it won't get done. And then the decision will have been made, by the speaker, that it was a political decision, not about the country. It would -- concern about tearing the president down instead of building America up. Because everyone will tell you, at the minimum, 180,000 more jobs. Our GDP goes up. We're stronger. We're stronger in the negotiations.

So I don't understand who out there is saying no to this. I don't hear speaker saying she's against it. She says she can't to get to a yes. The timing of waiting only makes it harder.

BARTIROMO: When you say we want to get to a "yes," I mean, look, we all remember the picture of the president there with the head of Mexico, the head of China (ph), signing on the dotted line.

MCCARTHY: Almost a year ago.

BARTIROMO: They already agreed to it. So when -- when you saying we're going to get to this, do -- are you saying that there's a chance that this can be opened up and then they have to agree to it again? I mean they already agreed to what's on paper.

MCCARTHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So how are we getting to this?

And there's a little softening in the air. Unexpectedly last week China removed some ag tariffs on soybeans and pork. They've had a tremendous problem with pork, which is a staple of their diet.

BARTIROMO: That's the point I made, they need our pork, they've got swine flu in 250 million pigs.

KUDLOW: They need -- I mean I think they need our beef, you know. When I was over there, I don't know a year, year and a half ago, my first trip to Beijing we had a couple of dinners and I would have preferred a Chinese takeout in New York City than what they fed me there.

BARTIROMO: Oh my goodness.

KUDLOW: I told Vice Premier Liu He, somewhat jokingly, you know I can't help myself, he really could use our steak because I wasn't sure what this stuff was that they were serving me, yes.

BARTRIOMO: Oh my god.

KUDLOW: But I will say this, better to talk than not to talk and the talks are proceeding. And they eased up on some of their requirements on the embargos. And the president also, in a good will gesture, deferred some our tariff expectations.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: So, you know, let us see --

BARTIROMO: So you say there's music in the air, you said the other day.

KUDLOW: Let us see. There's a little music in the air.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: I never predict --

BARTIROMO: But wasn't it Leo -- wasn't it Liu He who said, yes, I'm going to go back to China with this deal, we're 90 percent there and then he got to China and the hardline said, no.

KUDLOW: Yes, that's quite right.

BARTIROMO: So, how -- what's going to change with Liu He this time?

KUDLOW: I don't know. Again, I don't want to predict at all. We thought we were pretty close, they pulled back.

BARTIROMO: All right.

KUDLOW: That was a great disappointment. The president then took some tougher actions and he wasn't -- since then --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: -- the president has not been satisfied with the progress, but again, as a sharp negotiator, the president keeps saying, we must talk and if a good deal is on the table he would look at it, right, might even take it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: But it has to be a good deal.

BARTIROMO: Right.

KUDLOW: On the other hand, Maria, we're growing and they're not.

BARTIROMO: Right. Well, we got --

KUDLOW: And for years, China has moved wrong way.

BARTIROMO: But, we're slowing --

KUDLOW: They have reduced --

BARTIROMO: -- 3.1 percent to 2.1 percent in the second quarter.

KUDLOW: Well, let's see how the year plays out. It's interesting to me.

BARTIROMO: OK.

KUDLOW: Let's see how this year -- because these new numbers coming in on production and sales and consumers trying -- and jobs, by the by, I think our economy is outperforming expectations and by the by, incentives work.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: So, if you lower taxes, you lower regulations, you move to lower trade barriers, you open up the oil sector. I mean, look at what Iran's done, Iran deserves huge blame for the Saudi story, right?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: But had almost no impact except for the first 15 minutes of trading --

BARTIROMO: Great point.

KUDLOW: -- because we are producing 12.5 million barrels a day. I mean, wow.

BARTIROMO: A lot on the line. Larry, it's good to see you. Thank you so much.

KUDLOW: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Larry Kudlow. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. AT&T is being pressured to sell DirecTV amid mounting problems for the company. There is an activist investor involved, Gerri Willis is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with more. Gerri?

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS: Hey Maria, that's right. So we're seeing AT&T shares higher as it considers parting ways with its DirecTV unit. The CEO Randall Stevenson under pressure to change his strategy, to go to streaming media -- that business pressure from investor Elliot Management that owns a $3.2 billion stake in the company.

The most likely outcome of all this is that DirecTV and Dish would get married, would unite in one company. I want to tell you a little bit about U.S. Steel here for a second, that stock down pretty much 11 percent at my last look -- 12.85 percent on deteriorating market conditions in Europe. They are guiding lower on earnings. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right Gerri, thank you so much.

We did have the Philly Fed (ph) and the jobless claims out, we're going to get final thoughts for this -- I'll start panel when we come right back, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from this all-star panel, Byron York.

BYRON YORK, WASHINGTON EXAMINER: On trade, if you put together the Kevin McCarthy and the Larry Kudlow interviews talking about the relationship between the China thing and the USMCA.

First of all, Kudlow had incredibly nice conciliatory things to say about Speaker Pelosi --

BARTIROMO: I know --

YORK: Couldn't have been nicer.

BARTIROMO: I think he was speaking to her.

YORK: Couldn't have been nicer, and he pointed out total trade with Canada and Mexico is twice what it is with China --

BARTIROMO: He says $1.4 trillion --

YORK: Which is -- and Kevin McCarthy said pass this Mexico deal and that'll put pressure on the Chinese.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, good point. John?

JON HILSENRATH, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL, SENIOR WRITER: Well first on Larry Kudlow. He's a nice guy, I'm not surprised to hear him say nice things about Nancy Pelosi --

BARTIROMO: He's a very nice guy.

HILSENRATH: But you know, I want to talk about stocks and the fed. Stock futures are point up today, and here I think is why. The market got some much needed insight in to how the fed is managing this slowdown. Jay Powell was going to go at his own pace, he might cut rates a little bit more. But he's not going to get pushed in to doing it by either the market or the fed, and I think the market liked that certainty that it got.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, and also maybe it was the Philadelphia Federal Reserve that came out -- the index came out -- it dropped to 12 but it was higher than expected, markets turned around.

Dagan (ph) -- thank you so much Dagan (ph), Jon and Byron good to see you. Let's get right to David Asman, Varney & Co. begins now, have a great day everybody --

DAVID ASMAN: Dynamite show, Maria --

BARTIROMO: David Asman's in for Stuart.
